Figure 45. An even greater increase in yield per unit of capital creates a patterns of overshoot and collapse in the harvest (A), the economic capital (B), and the resource (C).

图 45. 单位资本的收益进一步增加，导致收获（A）、经济资本（B）和资源（C）出现过度增长和崩溃的模式。

If the fishing technology gets even better, the boats can go on operating economically even at very low fish densities. The result can be a nearly complete wipeout both of the fish and of the fishing industry. The consequence is the marine equivalent of desertification. The fish have been turned, for all practical purposes, into a nonrenewable resource. Figure 45 illustrates this scenario.

如果捕鱼技术进一步改进，即使鱼群密度极低，渔船也能继续经济高效地运营。其结果可能是鱼类和渔业几乎彻底灭绝。这相当于海洋版的沙漠化。实际上，鱼类已经变成了一种不可再生资源。图 45 展示了这种情况。

Nonrenewable resources are stock -limited. The entire stock is available at once, and can be extracted at any rate (limited mainly by extraction capital). But since the stock is not renewed, the faster the extraction rate, the shorter the lifetime of the resource.
不可再生资源具有储量限制。所有储量同时可用，且可以以任何速度开采（主要受开采资本限制）。但由于储量无法再生，开采速度越快，资源寿命就越短。
Renewable resources are flow limited. They can support extraction or harvest indefinitely, but only at a finite flow rate equal to their regeneration rate. If they are extracted faster than they regenerate, they may eventually be driven below a critical threshold and become, for all practical purposes, nonrenewable.
可再生资源的流量是有限的。它们可以无限期地被开采或利用，但流量必须有限，且等于其再生速度。如果开采速度超过再生速度，最终可能会低于临界阈值，实际上就变成了不可再生资源。

In many real economies based on real renewable resources—as opposed to this simple model—the very small surviving population retains the potential to build its numbers back up again, once the capital driving the harvest is gone. The whole pattern is repeated, decades later. Very long term renewable-resource cycles like these have been observed, for example, in the logging industry in New England, now in its third cycle of growth, overcutting, collapse, and eventual regeneration of the resource. But this is not true for all resource populations. More and more, increases in technology and harvest efficiency have the ability to drive resource populations to extinction.

在许多基于真正可再生资源的现实经济体中——与这种简单的模型不同——即使数量极少的幸存种群，一旦驱动资源开采的资本耗尽，它们仍有潜力重新壮大自身。整个模式会在几十年后重演。例如，新英格兰的伐木业就展现了这种非常长期的可再生资源周期，目前正处于其第三个周期：增长、过度砍伐、崩溃，以及最终的资源再生。但这并非适用于所有资源种群。越来越多的技术进步和资源开采效率的提高，反而可能导致资源种群的灭绝。

Whether a real renewable resource system can survive overharvest depends on what happens to it during the time when the resource is severely depleted. A very small fish population may become especially vulnerable to pollution or storms or lack of genetic diversity. If this is a forest or grassland resource, the exposed soils may be vulnerable to erosion. Or the nearly empty ecological niche may be filled in by a competitor. Or perhaps the depleted resource can survive and rebuild itself again.

一个真正的可再生资源系统能否在过度捕捞的情况下幸存下来，取决于资源严重枯竭期间系统自身的变化。数量极少的鱼类种群可能特别容易受到污染、风暴或遗传多样性缺失的影响。如果是森林或草原资源，裸露的土壤可能容易受到侵蚀。或者，几乎空置的生态位可能被竞争者填补。又或者，枯竭的资源能够存活下来并自我恢复。

I’ve shown three sets of possible behaviors of this renewable resource system here:

我在这里展示了这种可再生资源系统可能出现的三种行为：

• overshoot and adjustment to a sustainable equilibrium,
• 过度波动和调整以达到可持续的平衡状态，
• overshoot beyond that equilibrium followed by oscillation around it, and
• 超出平衡点后，围绕平衡点振荡，并且
• overshoot followed by collapse of the resource and the industry dependent on the resource.
• 资源过度消耗后，资源及其依赖的产业将崩溃。

Which outcome actually occurs depends on two things. The first is the critical threshold beyond which the resource population’s ability to regenerate itself is damaged. The second is the rapidity and effectiveness of the balancing feedback loop that slows capital growth as the resource becomes depleted. If the feedback is fast enough to stop capital growth before the critical threshold is reached, the whole system comes smoothly into equilibrium. If the balancing feedback is slower and less effective, the system oscillates. If the balancing loop is very weak, so that capital can go on growing even as the resource is reduced below its threshold ability to regenerate itself, the resource and the industry both collapse.

最终结果取决于两点。第一点是资源种群自我再生能力受损的临界阈值。第二点是资源枯竭时减缓资本增长的平衡反馈回路的速度和有效性。如果反馈足够迅速，能够在达到临界阈值之前阻止资本增长，整个系统就能平稳地达到平衡。如果平衡反馈较慢且效果不佳，系统就会出现波动。如果平衡回路非常薄弱，以至于即使资源减少到低于其自我再生能力的阈值，资本仍然可以继续增长，那么资源和产业都将崩溃。

Neither renewable nor nonrenewable limits to growth allow a physical stock to grow forever, but the constraints they impose are dynamically quite different. The difference comes because of the difference between stocks and flows.

无论是可再生能源还是不可再生能源，其增长限制都不允许实物存量无限增长，但它们所施加的限制在动态上却截然不同。这种差异源于存量和流量之间的区别。

The trick, as with all the behavioral possibilities of complex systems, is to recognize what structures contain which latent behaviors, and what conditions release those behaviors—and, where possible, to arrange the structures and conditions to reduce the probability of destructive behaviors and to encourage the possibility of beneficial ones.

与复杂系统的所有行为可能性一样，诀窍在于认识到哪些结构包含哪些潜在行为，以及哪些条件会释放这些行为——并且，在可能的情况下，安排结构和条件，以降低破坏性行为的可能性，并鼓励有益行为的可能性。

#↩

PART TWO

第二部分

Systems and Us

系统与我们

#↩

— THREE —

- 三 -

Why Systems Work So Well

为什么系统运行如此高效

_____________

If the land mechanism as a whole is good, then every part is good, whether we understand it or not. If the biota, in the course of aeons, has built something we like but do not understand, then who but a fool would discard seemingly useless parts? To keep every cog and wheel is the first precaution of intelligent tinkering.
如果整个陆地机制运转良好，那么无论我们是否理解，每个部分都是有益的。如果生物群落历经亿万年构建出我们喜爱却不理解的事物，那么除了傻瓜，谁会丢弃看似无用的部件呢？保留每一个齿轮和部件，是明智改造的首要原则。

—Aldo Leopold, 1 forester

——奥尔多·利奥波德， 1 林业家

Chapter Two introduced simple systems that create their own behavior based on their structures. Some are quite elegant—surviving the buffeting of the world—and, within limits, regaining their composure and proceeding on about their business of maintaining a room’s temperature, depleting an oil field, or bringing into balance the size of a fishing fleet with the productivity of a fishery resource.

第二章介绍了能够根据自身结构产生行为的简单系统。有些系统非常精妙——能够经受住外界的冲击——并且在一定范围内，能够恢复自身平衡，继续履行其职责，例如维持房间温度、开采油田或平衡渔船规模与渔业资源生产力。

If pushed too far, systems may well fall apart or exhibit heretofore unobserved behavior. But, by and large, they manage quite well. And that is the beauty of systems: They can work so well. When systems work well, we see a kind of harmony in their functioning. Think of a community kicking in to high gear to respond to a storm. People work long hours to help victims, talents and skills emerge; once the emergency is over, life goes back to “normal.”

如果过度运转，系统很可能会崩溃或出现以前从未观察到的行为。但总的来说，它们运转得相当不错。这就是系统的魅力所在：它们可以如此高效地运作。当系统运转良好时，我们会看到其运行中呈现出一种和谐的平衡。想象一下，一个社区全力以赴应对风暴。人们长时间工作以帮助受害者，各种才能和技能得以展现；一旦紧急情况结束，生活便恢复了“正常”。

Why do systems work so well? Consider the properties of highly functional systems—machines or human communities or ecosystems—which are familiar to you. Chances are good that you may have observed one of three characteristics: resilience, self-organization, or hierarchy.

为什么有些系统运行如此高效？想想那些你熟悉的、功能强大的系统——机器、人类社群或生态系统——它们的特性。你很可能已经观察到以下三个特征之一：韧性、自组织或层级结构。

Resilience

弹力

Placing a system in a straitjacket of constancy can cause fragility to evolve.
让一个系统陷入一成不变的束缚，会导致其变得脆弱。
—C. S. Holling, 2 ecologist
—C. S. Holling，生态学家

Resilience has many definitions, depending on the branch of engineering, ecology, or system science doing the defining. For our purposes, the normal dictionary meaning will do: “the ability to bounce or spring back into shape, position, etc., after being pressed or stretched. Elasticity. The ability to recover strength, spirits, good humor, or any other aspect quickly.” Resilience is a measure of a system’s ability to survive and persist within a variable environment. The opposite of resilience is brittleness or rigidity.

韧性有很多定义，取决于工程学、生态学或系统科学等不同分支的定义。就本文而言，我们采用词典中的常用定义即可：“在受到挤压或拉伸后恢复原状的能力。弹性。迅速恢复力量、精神、好心情或其他任何方面的能力。”韧性衡量的是一个系统在多变的环境中生存和持续发展的能力。韧性的反义词是脆弱性或僵化性。

Resilience arises from a rich structure of many feedback loops that can work in different ways to restore a system even after a large perturbation. A single balancing loop brings a system stock back to its desired state. Resilience is provided by several such loops, operating through different mechanisms, at different time scales, and with redundancy—one kicking in if another one fails.

韧性源于一个由众多反馈回路组成的复杂结构，这些回路能够以不同的方式运作，即使在遭受巨大扰动后也能使系统恢复正常。单个平衡回路可以将系统恢复到期望状态。韧性则由多个这样的回路共同提供，它们通过不同的机制、在不同的时间尺度上运行，并且具有冗余性——当一个回路失效时，另一个回路会立即启动。

A set of feedback loops that can restore or rebuild feedback loops is resilience at a still higher level—meta-resilience, if you will. Even higher meta-meta- resilience comes from feedback loops that can learn , create , design , and evolve ever more complex restorative structures. Systems that can do this are self-organizing, which will be the next surprising system characteristic I come to.

能够修复或重建反馈回路的反馈回路集合，代表着更高层次的韧性——姑且称之为元韧性。更高层次的元元韧性则来自于能够学习、创造、设计和演化出日益复杂的修复结构的反馈回路。能够做到这一点的系统是自组织的，而这正是我接下来要提到的系统的一个令人惊讶的特性。

The human body is an astonishing example of a resilient system. It can fend off thousands of different kinds of invaders, it can tolerate wide ranges of temperature and wide variations in food supply, it can reallocate blood supply, repair rips, gear up or slow down metabolism, and compensate to some extent for missing or defective parts. Add to it a self-organizing intelligence that can learn, socialize, design technologies, and even transplant body parts, and you have a formidably resilient system—although not infinitely so, because, so far at least, no human body-plus-intelligence has been resilient enough to keep itself or any other body from eventually dying.

人体是一个令人惊叹的韧性系统。它能抵御成千上万种不同的入侵者，能适应巨大的温度变化和食物供应的剧烈波动，能重新分配血液供应，修复损伤，加速或减缓新陈代谢，并在一定程度上弥补缺失或缺陷的器官。再加上能够学习、社交、设计技术甚至进行器官移植的自组织智能，你就拥有了一个极其强大的韧性系统——尽管这种韧性并非无限的，因为至少到目前为止，还没有任何一个结合了智能的人体能够强大到足以阻止自身或其他任何物体最终死亡。

There are always limits to resilience.
韧性总是有限度的。

Ecosystems are also remarkably resilient, with multiple species holding each other in check, moving around in space, multiplying or declining over time in response to weather and the availability of nutrients and the impacts of human activities. Populations and ecosystems also have the ability to “learn” and evolve through their incredibly rich genetic variability. They can, given enough time, come up with whole new systems to take advantage of changing opportunities for life support.

生态系统也具有惊人的恢复力，多种物种相互制约，在空间中迁徙，并随着时间推移，根据天气、营养物质的供应以及人类活动的影响而增殖或衰落。种群和生态系统还拥有通过其极其丰富的遗传变异性进行“学习”和进化的能力。只要有足够的时间，它们就能创造出全新的系统，以利用不断变化的生存机会。

Resilience is not the same thing as being static or constant over time. Resilient systems can be very dynamic. Short-term oscillations, or periodic outbreaks, or long cycles of succession, climax, and collapse may in fact be the normal condition, which resilience acts to restore!

韧性并非指长期保持静止或恒定不变。具有韧性的系统可能非常动态。短期波动、周期性爆发或漫长的演替、高峰和崩溃循环，实际上可能才是正常状态，而韧性的作用就在于恢复这种状态！

And, conversely, systems that are constant over time can be unresilient. This distinction between static stability and resilience is important. Static stability is something you can see; it’s measured by variation in the condition of a system week by week or year by year. Resilience is something that may be very hard to see, unless you exceed its limits, overwhelm and damage the balancing loops, and the system structure breaks down. Because resilience may not be obvious without a whole-system view, people often sacrifice resilience for stability, or for productivity, or for some other more immediately recognizable system property.

反之，长期保持不变的系统也可能缺乏韧性。区分静态稳定性和韧性至关重要。静态稳定性是显而易见的，可以通过系统每周或每年的状态变化来衡量。而韧性则很难察觉，除非超出其极限，破坏平衡回路，导致系统结构崩溃。由于缺乏系统整体视角，韧性可能并不明显，人们常常为了稳定性、生产力或其他更容易识别的系统属性而牺牲韧性。

• Injections of genetically engineered bovine growth hormone increase the milk production of a cow without proportionately increasing the cow’s food intake. The hormone diverts some of the cow’s metabolic energy from other bodily functions to milk production. (Cattle breeding over centuries has done much the same thing but not to the same degree.) The cost of increased production is lowered resilience. The cow is less healthy, less long-lived, more dependent on human management.
注射转基因牛生长激素可以提高奶牛的产奶量，而不会相应增加奶牛的采食量。这种激素会将奶牛的部分代谢能量从其他生理功能转移到产奶上。（几个世纪以来，牛的育种也起到了类似的作用，但程度远不及此。）提高产奶量的代价是降低了奶牛的抵抗力。奶牛的健康状况下降，寿命缩短，并且更加依赖人工管理。
• Just-in-time deliveries of products to retailers or parts to manufacturers have reduced inventory instabilities and brought down costs in many industries. The just-in-time model also has made the production system more vulnerable, however, to perturbations in fuel supply, traffic flow, computer breakdown, labor availability, and other possible glitches.
• 向零售商即时交付产品或向制造商即时交付零部件，降低了许多行业的库存不稳定性，并降低了成本。然而，即时生产模式也使生产系统更容易受到燃料供应、交通流量、计算机故障、劳动力短缺以及其他潜在故障的影响。
• Hundreds of years of intensive management of the forests of Europe gradually have replaced native ecosystems with single age, single-species plantations, often of nonnative trees. These are designed to yield wood and pulp at a high rate indefinitely. However, without multiple species interacting with each other and drawing and returning varying combinations of nutrients from the soil, these forests have lost their resilience. They seem to be especially vulnerable to a new form of insult: industrial air pollution.
数百年来，欧洲森林的集约化管理逐渐将原生生态系统替换为单一树龄、单一树种的人工林，其中许多树种并非本地树种。这些人工林旨在无限期地高产木材和纸浆。然而，由于缺乏多种树种间的相互作用，以及从土壤中吸收和释放不同组合的养分，这些森林已经失去了自身的恢复力。它们似乎尤其容易受到一种新型侵害：工业空气污染。

Many chronic diseases, such as cancer and heart disease, come from breakdown of resilience mechanisms that repair DNA, keep blood vessels flexible, or control cell division. Ecological disasters in many places come from loss of resilience, as species are removed from ecosystems, soil chemistry and biology are disturbed, or toxins build up. Large organizations of all kinds, from corporations to governments, lose their resilience simply because the feedback mechanisms by which they sense and respond to their environment have to travel through too many layers of delay and distortion. (More on that in a minute, when we come to hierarchies.)

许多慢性疾病，例如癌症和心脏病，都源于修复DNA、维持血管弹性或控制细胞分裂等恢复机制的崩溃。许多地方的生态灾难也源于恢复力的丧失，例如物种从生态系统中消失、土壤化学和生物特性遭到破坏，或毒素积累。从企业到政府，各种大型组织都会丧失其恢复力，原因很简单：它们感知和响应环境的反馈机制需要经过太多延迟和扭曲的层级。（稍后在讨论层级结构时会更详细地阐述这一点。）

I think of resilience as a plateau upon which the system can play, performing its normal functions in safety. A resilient system has a big plateau, a lot of space over which it can wander, with gentle, elastic walls that will bounce it back, if it comes near a dangerous edge. As a system loses its resilience, its plateau shrinks, and its protective walls become lower and more rigid, until the system is operating on a knife edge, likely to fall off in one direction or another whenever it makes a move. Loss of resilience can come as a surprise, because the system usually is paying much more attention to its play than to its playing space. One day it does something it has done a hundred times before and crashes.

我认为韧性就像一个平台，系统可以在其上安全地运行，履行其正常功能。一个有韧性的系统拥有一个宽广的平台，广阔的空间供其自由探索，平台边缘柔和而富有弹性，一旦系统接近危险边缘，便会将其弹回。随着系统韧性的丧失，平台逐渐缩小，保护性的边界也变得低矮而僵硬，最终系统如同走在刀刃上，任何举动都可能使其跌落。韧性的丧失往往令人猝不及防，因为系统通常更关注自身的行为，而非其活动空间。或许有一天，它做了一件已经做过无数次的事情，却突然崩溃了。

Systems need to be managed not only for productivity or stability, they also need to be managed for resilience —the ability to recover from perturbation, the ability to restore or repair themselves.
系统不仅需要为了生产力或稳定性而进行管理，还需要为了韧性而进行管理——即从扰动中恢复的能力，自我修复或恢复的能力。

Awareness of resilience enables one to see many ways to preserve or enhance a system’s own restorative powers. That awareness is behind the encouragement of natural ecosystems on farms, so that predators can take on more of the job of controlling pests. It is behind “holistic” health care that tries not only to cure disease but also to build up a body’s internal resistance. It is behind aid programs that do more than give food or money—that try to change the circumstances that obstruct peoples’ ability to provide their own food or money.

对韧性的认知使人们能够发现许多保护或增强系统自身修复能力的方法。这种认知促使人们在农场推广自然生态系统，让捕食者承担更多控制害虫的工作。它也推动了“整体”医疗保健的发展，这种医疗保健不仅致力于治愈疾病，还力求增强人体的内在抵抗力。此外，它也促成了援助项目，这些项目不仅仅提供食物或金钱，而是努力改变阻碍人们自给自足的困境。

Self-Organization

自组织

[Evolution] appears to be not a series of accidents the course of which is determined only by the change of environments during earth history and the resulting struggle for existence, . . . but is governed by definite laws. . . . The discovery of these laws constitutes one of the most important tasks of the future.
【进化】似乎并非一系列偶然事件，其进程并非仅仅由地球历史上环境的变化以及由此产生的生存斗争所决定，而是受制于明确的规律……发现这些规律是未来最重要的任务之一。
—Ludwig von Bertalanffy, 3 biologist
—Ludwig von Bertalanffy， 3 生物学家

The most marvelous characteristic of some complex systems is their ability to learn, diversify, complexify, evolve. It is the ability of a single fertilized ovum to generate, out of itself, the incredible complexity of a mature frog, or chicken, or person. It is the ability of nature to have diversified millions of fantastic species out of a puddle of organic chemicals. It is the ability of a society to take the ideas of burning coal, making steam, pumping water, and specializing labor, and develop them eventually into an automobile assembly plant, a city of skyscrapers, a worldwide network of communications.

某些复杂系统最令人惊叹之处在于它们学习、多样化、复杂化和进化的能力。这就像一个受精卵能够从自身孕育出成熟的青蛙、鸡或人这样令人难以置信的复杂个体。这就像大自然能够从一滩有机化学物质中创造出数百万种奇妙的物种。这就像一个社会能够将燃烧煤炭、产生蒸汽、抽水和劳动分工等想法发展成汽车组装厂、摩天大楼林立的城市以及遍布全球的通信网络。

This capacity of a system to make its own structure more complex is called self-organization . You see self-organization in a small, mechanistic way whenever you see a snowflake, or ice feathers on a poorly insulated window, or a supersaturated solution suddenly forming a garden of crystals. You see self-organization in a more profound way whenever a seed sprouts, or a baby learns to speak, or a neighborhood decides to come together to oppose a toxic waste dump.

系统使其自身结构变得更加复杂的这种能力被称为自组织。每当我们看到雪花、隔热不良的窗户上结成的冰柱，或者过饱和溶液突然形成晶簇时，你就能看到自组织的微观机械表现。而每当种子发芽、婴儿学会说话，或者社区居民团结起来反对建设有毒垃圾填埋场时，你就能看到自组织的更深层次表现。

Self-organization is such a common property, particularly of living systems, that we take it for granted. If we didn’t, we would be dazzled by the unfolding systems of our world. And if we weren’t nearly blind to the property of self-organization, we would do better at encouraging, rather than destroying, the self-organizing capacities of the systems of which we are a part.

自组织是一种非常普遍的特性，尤其是在生命系统中，以至于我们习以为常。如果我们不这样认为，就会被我们世界中不断演化的系统所震撼。如果我们对自组织的特性不那么视而不见，我们就能更好地鼓励而非破坏我们身处其中的系统的自组织能力。

Like resilience, self-organization is often sacrificed for purposes of short-term productivity and stability. Productivity and stability are the usual excuses for turning creative human beings into mechanical adjuncts to production processes. Or for narrowing the genetic variability of crop plants. Or for establishing bureaucracies and theories of knowledge that treat people as if they were only numbers.

与韧性一样，自组织能力常常为了短期生产力和稳定性而被牺牲。生产力和稳定性通常被用来作为借口，将富有创造力的人类变成生产过程的机械附属品，或是缩小农作物的遗传多样性，或是建立官僚机构和知识理论，将人仅仅视为数字。

Self-organization produces heterogeneity and unpredictability. It is likely come up with whole new structures, whole new ways of doing things. It requires freedom and experimentation, and a certain amount of disorder. These conditions that encourage self-organization often can be scary for individuals and threatening to power structures. As a consequence, education systems may restrict the creative powers of children instead of stimulating those powers. Economic policies may lean toward supporting established, powerful enterprises rather than upstart, new ones. And many governments prefer their people not to be too self-organizing.

自组织会产生异质性和不可预测性。它很可能催生全新的结构和全新的做事方式。它需要自由和实验精神，以及一定程度的无序。这些鼓励自组织的条件往往令个人感到恐惧，并对权力结构构成威胁。因此，教育体系可能会限制而非激发儿童的创造力。经济政策可能倾向于扶持成熟的、实力雄厚的企业，而非新兴企业。许多政府也不希望民众过度自组织。

Fortunately, self-organization is such a basic property of living systems that even the most overbearing power structure can never fully kill it, although in the name of law and order, self-organization can be suppressed for long, barren, cruel, boring periods.

幸运的是，自组织是生命系统的基本属性，即使是最专横的权力结构也无法完全扼杀它，尽管以法律和秩序的名义，自组织可能会被压制很长一段时间，变得贫瘠、残酷、无聊。

Systems theorists used to think that self-organization was such a complex property of systems that it could never be understood. Computers were used to model mechanistic, “deterministic” systems, not evolutionary ones, because it was suspected, without much thought, that evolutionary systems were simply not understandable.

系统论者过去认为，自组织是系统的一种极其复杂的属性，以至于永远无法理解。计算机被用来模拟机械的、“决定论的”系统，而不是演化系统，因为人们未经深思熟虑就怀疑演化系统根本无法理解。

New discoveries, however, suggest that just a few simple organizing principles can lead to wildly diverse self-organizing structures. Imagine a triangle with three equal sides. Add to the middle of each side another equilateral triangle, one-third the size of the first one. Add to each of the new sides another triangle, one-third smaller. And so on. The result is called a Koch snowflake. (See Figure 46 .) Its edge has tremendous length—but it can be contained within a circle. This structure is one simple example of fractal geometry—a realm of mathematics and art populated by elaborate shapes formed by relatively simple rules.

然而，新的发现表明，只需几个简单的组织原则就能产生极其多样的自组织结构。想象一个三边相等的三角形。在每条边的中间添加一个等边三角形，其大小是第一个三角形的三分之一。然后在每个新添加的边上再添加一个三角形，其大小是第一个三角形的三分之一。以此类推。最终得到的结构被称为科赫雪花（见图46）。它的边长非常大，但却可以包含在一个圆内。这种结构是分形几何的一个简单例子——分形几何是数学和艺术的一个领域，其中充满了由相对简单的规则构成的复杂形状。

Similarly, the delicate, beautiful, intricate structure of a stylized fern can be generated by a computer with just a few simple fractal rules. The differentiation of a single cell into a human being probably proceeds by some similar set of geometric rules, basically simple, but generating utter complexity. (It is because of fractal geometry that the average human lung has enough surface area to cover a tennis court.)

同样，只需几条简单的分形规则，计算机就能生成风格化蕨类植物精致、美丽、错综复杂的结构。单个细胞分化成人类的过程可能也遵循着类似的几何规则，这些规则本质上很简单，却能产生极其复杂的结构。（正是由于分形几何，人类肺部的平均表面积才足以覆盖一个网球场。）

Figure 46. Even a delicate and intricate pattern, such as the Koch snowflake shown here, can evolve from a simple set of organizing principles or decision rules.

图 46. 即使是像这里所示的科赫雪花这样精致复杂的图案，也可以从一组简单的组织原则或决策规则演变而来。

Here are some other examples of simple organizing rules that have led to self-organizing systems of great complexity:

以下是一些其他简单的组织规则的例子，这些规则造就了高度复杂的自组织系统：

• All of life, from viruses to redwood trees, from amoebas to elephants, is based on the basic organizing rules encapsulated in the chemistry of DNA, RNA, and protein molecules.
• 从病毒到红杉树，从变形虫到大象，所有生命都基于 DNA、RNA 和蛋白质分子化学中蕴含的基本组织规则。
• The agricultural revolution and all that followed started with the simple, shocking ideas that people could stay settled in one place, own land, select and cultivate crops.
• 农业革命及其后续发展始于一个简单而令人震惊的想法：人们可以定居在一个地方，拥有土地，选择和种植作物。
• “God created the universe with the earth at its center, the land with the castle at its center, and humanity with the Church at its center”—the organizing principle for the elaborate social and physical structures of Europe in the Middle Ages.
• “上帝创造了宇宙，以地球为中心；创造了陆地，以城堡为中心；创造了人类，以教会为中心”——这是中世纪欧洲复杂的社会和物质结构的组织原则。
• “God and morality are outmoded ideas; people should be objective and scientific, should own and multiply the means of production, and should treat people and nature as instrumental inputs to production”—the organizing principles of the Industrial Revolution.
• “上帝和道德是过时的观念；人们应该客观、科学，应该拥有和增加生产资料，应该把人和自然视为生产的工具性投入”——工业革命的组织原则。

Out of simple rules of self-organization can grow enormous, diversifying crystals of technology, physical structures, organizations, and cultures.

从简单的自组织规则中可以发展出庞大的、多样化的技术、物理结构、组织和文化晶体。

Systems often have the property of self-organization—the ability to structure themselves, to create new structure, to learn, diversify, and complexify. Even complex forms of self-organization may arise from relatively simple organizing rules—or may not.
系统通常具有自组织特性——即自我构建结构、创造新结构、学习、多样化和复杂化的能力。即使是复杂的自组织形式，也可能源于相对简单的组织规则，也可能并非如此。

Science knows now that self-organizing systems can arise from simple rules. Science, itself a self-organizing system, likes to think that all the complexity of the world must arise, ultimately, from simple rules. Whether that actually happens is something that science does not yet know.

科学现在知道，自组织系统可以从简单的规则中产生。科学本身就是一个自组织系统，它倾向于认为，世界上所有复杂的事物最终都必然源于简单的规则。但这是否真的如此，科学目前尚不得而知。

Hierarchy

等级制度

So, naturalists observe, a flea
因此，博物学家观察到，跳蚤
Has smaller Fleas that on him prey;
身上有体型较小的跳蚤，是它的猎物；
And these have smaller still to bite ‘em,
而这些小家伙还有更小的敌人来咬它们。
And so proceed ad infinitum.
如此循环往复，永无止境。
—Jonathan Swift, 4 Jonathan Swift, 18th century poet
——乔纳森·斯威夫特（Jonathan Swift），18世纪诗人

In the process of creating new structures and increasing complexity, one thing that a self-organizing system often generates is hierarchy .

在创建新结构和增加复杂性的过程中，自组织系统经常产生的一件事就是层级结构。

The world, or at least the parts of it humans think they understand, is organized in subsystems aggregated into larger subsystems, aggregated into still larger subsystems. A cell in your liver is a subsystem of an organ, which is a subsystem of you as an organism, and you are a subsystem of a family, an athletic team, a musical group, and so forth. These groups are subsystems of a town or city, and then a nation, and then the whole global socioeconomic system that dwells within the biosphere system. This arrangement of systems and subsystems is called a hierarchy.

世界，或者至少是人类自认为理解的世界部分，是由子系统构成的，这些子系统又聚合成更大的子系统，再聚合成更大的子系统。你肝脏中的一个细胞是某个器官的子系统，而这个器官又是你这个有机体的子系统，你又是家庭、运动队、乐队等等的子系统。这些群体又是城镇或城市的子系统，然后是国家，最终构成整个全球社会经济系统，而这个全球社会经济系统又存在于生物圈系统中。这种系统和子系统的组合被称为层级结构。

Corporate systems, military systems, ecological systems, economic systems, living organisms, are arranged in hierarchies. It is no accident that that is so. If subsystems can largely take care of themselves, regulate themselves, maintain themselves, and yet serve the needs of the larger system, while the larger system coordinates and enhances the functioning of the subsystems, a stable, resilient, and efficient structure results. It is hard to imagine how any other kind of arrangement could have come to be.

企业系统、军事系统、生态系统、经济系统、生物体，都以层级结构组织起来。这绝非偶然。如果各个子系统能够基本实现自我管理、自我调节、自我维护，同时又能满足更大系统的需求，而更大系统又能协调和提升各个子系统的功能，那么就会形成一个稳定、富有弹性且高效的结构。很难想象其他任何一种组织结构会如何形成。

INTERLUDE • Why the Universe Is Organized into Hierarchies—a Fable

插曲 • 宇宙为何呈层级结构——一个寓言

There once were two watchmakers, named Hora and Tempus. Both of them made fine watches, and they both had many customers. People dropped into their stores, and their phones rang constantly with new orders. Over the years, however, Hora prospered, while Tempus became poorer and poorer. That’s because Hora discovered the principle of hierarchy. . . .

从前有两个钟表匠，一个叫霍拉，一个叫坦普斯。他们都制作精美的手表，顾客也很多。人们经常光顾他们的店铺，电话铃声也响个不停，订单纷至沓来。然而，随着时间的推移，霍拉的生意越来越好，而坦普斯却越来越穷。这是因为霍拉发现了等级制度的原理……

The watches made by both Hora and Tempus consisted of about one thousand parts each. Tempus put his together in such a way that if he had one partly assembled and had to put it down—to answer the phone, say—it fell to pieces. When he came back to it, Tempus would have to start all over again. The more his customers phoned him, the harder it became for him to find enough uninterrupted time to finish a watch.

Hora 和 Tempus 制作的手表都由大约一千个零件组成。Tempus 的手表组装方式很特别，如果他组装到一半不得不放下——比如去接个电话——手表就会散架。等他回来继续组装时，就得从头再来。顾客的电话越多，他就越难找到足够的时间来完成一枚手表。

Hora’s watches were no less complex than those of Tempus, but he put together stable subassemblies of about ten elements each. Then he put ten of these subassemblies together into a larger assembly; and ten of those assemblies constituted the whole watch. Whenever Hora had to put down a partly completed watch to answer the phone, he lost only a small part of his work. So he made his watches much faster and more efficiently than did Tempus.

霍拉的腕表复杂程度丝毫不逊于坦普斯，但他将腕表组装成稳定的子组件，每个子组件大约包含十个零件。然后，他将十个这样的子组件组装成一个更大的组件；十个这样的组件最终构成整只腕表。每当霍拉不得不放下正在制作中的腕表去接电话时，他只会损失一小部分工作成果。因此，他制作腕表的速度和效率都远胜于坦普斯。

Complex systems can evolve from simple systems only if there are stable intermediate forms. The resulting complex forms will naturally be hierarchic. That may explain why hierarchies are so common in the systems nature presents to us. Among all possible complex forms, hierarchies are the only ones that have had the time to evolve. 5 Paraphrased from Herbert Simon,

复杂系统只有在存在稳定的中间形式的情况下才能从简单系统演化而来。由此产生的复杂形式自然会呈现层级结构。这或许可以解释为什么层级结构在自然界呈现给我们的系统中如此普遍。在所有可能的复杂形式中，只有层级结构有足够的时间演化。 5 （改编自赫伯特·西蒙）

Hierarchies are brilliant systems inventions, not only because they give a system stability and resilience, but also because they reduce the amount of information that any part of the system has to keep track of.

层级结构是绝妙的系统发明，不仅因为它赋予系统稳定性和弹性，还因为它减少了系统任何部分需要跟踪的信息量。

In hierarchical systems relationships within each subsystem are denser and stronger than relationships between subsystems. Everything is still connected to everything else, but not equally strongly. People in the same university department talk to each other more than they talk to people in other departments. The cells that constitute the liver are in closer communication with each other than they are with the cells of the heart. If these differential information links within and between each level of the hierarchy are designed right, feedback delays are minimized. No level is overwhelmed with information. The system works with efficiency and resilience.

在层级系统中，每个子系统内部的关系比子系统之间的关系更紧密、更牢固。所有事物仍然彼此相连，但联系的紧密程度并不相同。同一大学院系的人员之间的交流比与其他院系人员的交流更多。构成肝脏的细胞之间的交流比它们与心脏细胞之间的交流更密切。如果层级内部和层级之间这些差异化的信息链接设计得当，反馈延迟就会被最小化。任何层级都不会被过多的信息淹没。系统就能高效且稳健地运行。

Hierarchical systems are partially decomposable. They can be taken apart and the subsystems with their especially dense information links can function, at least partially, as systems in their own right. When hierarchies break down, they usually split along their subsystem boundaries. Much can be learned by taking apart systems at different hierarchical levels—cells or organs, for example—and studying them separately. Hence, systems thinkers would say, the reductionist dissection of regular science teaches us a lot. However, one should not lose sight of the important relationships that each subsystem to the others and to the higher levels of the hierarchy, or one will be in for surprises.

层级系统具有部分可分解性。它们可以被拆解，而各个子系统凭借其高度密集的信息联系，至少可以部分地作为独立的系统发挥作用。当层级结构瓦解时，它们通常会沿着子系统边界分裂。通过将系统（例如细胞或器官）拆解到不同的层级并分别进行研究，我们可以学到很多东西。因此，系统思考者会说，对常规科学进行还原论式的剖析能教会我们很多东西。然而，我们不应忽视每个子系统与其他子系统以及与更高层级系统之间重要的相互关系，否则我们将面临意想不到的发现。

If you have a liver disease, for example, a doctor usually can treat it without paying much attention to your heart or your tonsils (to stay on the same hierarchical level) or your personality (to move up a level or two) or the DNA in the nuclei of the liver cells (to move down several levels). There are just enough exceptions to that rule, however, to reinforce the necessity of stepping back to consider the whole hierarchy. Maybe your job exposes you to a chemical that is damaging your liver. Maybe the disease originates in a malfunction of the DNA.

例如，如果你患有肝病，医生通常无需过多关注你的心脏或扁桃体（保持在同一层级），也无需过多关注你的性格（提升一两层级），更无需关注肝细胞核内的DNA（降低几层级）。然而，这条规则也存在一些例外，足以强调我们需要退后一步，从整体层面来考虑疾病的层级结构。或许你的工作让你接触到某种损害肝脏的化学物质。或许这种疾病源于DNA功能障碍。

What you need to think about may change over time, as self-organizing systems evolve new degrees of hierarchy and integration. The energy systems of nations were once almost completely decomposable one from another. That is no longer true. People whose thinking has not evolved as fast as the energy economy has may be shocked to discover how dependent they have become on resources and decisions halfway around the world.

随着自组织系统演化出新的层级和整合程度，你需要考虑的问题也会随之改变。各国能源系统曾经几乎完全彼此独立，但如今已不再如此。那些思维方式未能跟上能源经济发展步伐的人们，或许会震惊地发现，他们已经对远在地球另一端的资源和决策产生了多么深的依赖。

You can watch self-organizing systems form hierarchies. A self-employed person gets too much work and hires some helpers. A small, informal nonprofit organization attracts many members and a bigger budget and one day the members decide, “Hey, we need someone to organize all this.” A cluster of dividing cells differentiates into special functions and generates a branching circulatory system to feed all cells, and a branching nervous system to coordinate them.

你可以观察自组织系统如何形成层级结构。比如，一个个体户工作太多，于是雇佣了一些帮手。一个小型非正式的非营利组织吸引了众多成员，预算也越来越充足，有一天，成员们决定：“我们需要有人来组织这一切。” 一群分裂的细胞分化成具有特定功能的细胞，并生成一个分支状的循环系统来为所有细胞提供营养，以及一个分支状的神经系统来协调它们。

Hierarchies evolve from the lowest level up—from the pieces to the whole, from cell to organ to organism, from individual to team, from actual production to management of production. Early farmers decided to come together and form cities for self-protection and for making trade more efficient. Life started with single-cell bacteria, not with elephants. The original purpose of a hierarchy is always to help its originating subsystems do their jobs better. This is something, unfortunately, that both the higher and the lower levels of a greatly articulated hierarchy easily can forget. Therefore, many systems are not meeting our goals because of malfunctioning hierarchies.

层级结构自下而上演化——从局部到整体，从细胞到器官到有机体，从个体到团队，从实际生产到生产管理。早期的农民为了自卫和提高贸易效率而聚集在一起，建立城市。生命起源于单细胞细菌，而非大象。层级结构的最初目的始终是帮助其组成子系统更好地完成各自的工作。然而，不幸的是，即使是结构复杂的层级结构，其上层和下层都容易忘记这一点。因此，许多系统未能实现我们的目标，正是由于层级结构失灵所致。

If a team member is more interested in personal glory than in the team winning, he or she can cause the team to lose. If a body cell breaks free from its hierarchical function and starts multiplying wildly, we call it a cancer. If students think their purpose is to maximize personal grades instead of seeking knowledge, cheating and other counterproductive behaviors break out. If a single corporation bribes the government to favor that corporation, the advantages of the competitive market and the good of the whole society are eroded.

如果团队成员更看重个人荣誉而非团队胜利，就可能导致团队失败。如果一个体细胞脱离其层级功能并开始疯狂增殖，我们就称之为癌症。如果学生认为学习的目的是追求个人高分而非求知，作弊和其他适得其反的行为就会出现。如果一家公司贿赂政府以求获得优待，竞争市场的优势和整个社会的利益就会受到损害。

When a subsystem’s goals dominate at the expense of the total system’s goals, the resulting behavior is called suboptimization .

当一个子系统的目标凌驾于整个系统的目标之上时，由此产生的行为称为次优化。

Just as damaging as suboptimization, of course, is the problem of too much central control. If the brain controlled each cell so tightly that the cell could not perform its self-maintenance functions, the whole organism could die. If central rules and regulations prevent students or faculty from exploring fields of knowledge freely, the purpose of the university is not served. The coach of a team might interfere with the on-the-spot perceptions of a good player, to the detriment of the team. Economic examples of overcontrol from the top, from companies to nations, are the causes of some of the great catastrophes of history, all of which are by no means behind us.

当然，与次优决策同样有害的是中央控制过度的问题。如果大脑对每个细胞的控制过于严密，以至于细胞无法进行自我维持，那么整个机体都可能死亡。如果中央规章制度限制了学生或教职员工自由探索知识领域，那么大学存在的意义就无法实现。球队教练可能会干预优秀球员的临场判断，从而损害球队的利益。从公司到国家，经济领域中自上而下的过度控制是历史上一些重大灾难的根源，而这些灾难至今仍未完全消失。

To be a highly functional system, hierarchy must balance the welfare, freedoms, and responsibilities of the subsystems and total system—there must be enough central control to achieve coordination toward the large system goal, and enough autonomy to keep all subsystems flourishing, functioning, and self-organizing.

要成为一个高度运转的系统，层级结构必须平衡子系统和整个系统的福利、自由和责任——必须有足够的中央控制来实现朝着大系统目标的协调，并且要有足够的自主权来保持所有子系统的繁荣、运转和自组织。

Resilience, self-organization, and hierarchy are three of the reasons dynamic systems can work so well. Promoting or managing for these properties of a system can improve its ability to function well over the long term—to be sustainable. But watching how systems behave also can be full of surprises.

韧性、自组织和层级结构是动态系统能够高效运作的三大原因。促进或管理系统的这些特性可以提高其长期有效运作的能力，从而实现可持续发展。但观察系统的运行方式也可能充满惊喜。

Hierarchical systems evolve from the bottom up. The purpose of the upper layers of the hierarchy is to serve the purposes of the lower layers.
层级系统是从下往上演化的。层级结构中上层的目的是服务于下层的目的。
#↩

— FOUR —

— 四 —

Why Systems Surprise Us

为什么系统会让我们感到意外

_____________

The trouble . . . is that we are terrifyingly ignorant. The most learned of us are ignorant. . . . The acquisition of knowledge always involves the revelation of ignorance—almost is the revelation of ignorance. Our knowledge of the world instructs us first of all that the world is greater than our knowledge of it.
问题在于……我们无知得可怕。即使是最有学问的人，也难免无知……知识的获取总是伴随着无知的显现——几乎就是无知的显现。我们对世界的认知首先告诉我们，世界远比我们对它的了解要广阔得多。
—Wendell Berry, 1 writer and Kentucky farmer
——温德尔·贝瑞，作家兼肯塔基州农民

The simple systems in the zoo may have perplexed you with their behavior. They continue to surprise me, although I have been teaching them for years. That you and I are surprised says as much about us as it does about dynamic systems. The interactions between what I think I know about dynamic systems and my experience of the real world never fails to be humbling. They keep reminding me of three truths:

动物园里那些看似简单的系统，它们的行为或许曾让你感到困惑。即便我已经研究它们多年，它们依然让我感到惊讶。你我感到惊讶，这既反映了我们自身的局限，也揭示了动态系统的本质。我对动态系统的认知与我对现实世界的体验之间的互动，总是让我感到自身的渺小。它们不断提醒我三个真理：

1. Everything we think we know about the world is a model. Every word and every language is a model. All maps and statistics, books and databases, equations and computer programs are models. So are the ways I picture the world in my head—my mental models. None of these is or ever will be the real world.
1. 我们自以为了解的一切关于世界的知识都是一种模型。每一个词、每一种语言都是模型。所有的地图、统计数据、书籍、数据库、方程式和计算机程序都是模型。我脑海中对世界的想象——我的心理模型——也是如此。这些都不是，也永远不会是真实的世界。
2. Our models usually have a strong congruence with the world. That is why we are such a successful species in the biosphere. Especially complex and sophisticated are the mental models we develop from direct, intimate experience of nature, people, and organizations immediately around us.
2. 我们的模型通常与现实世界高度吻合。正因如此，我们才能在生物圈中如此成功。我们通过直接、深入地体验周围的自然、人以及组织而形成的心理模型，尤其复杂精妙。
3. However, and conversely, our models fall far short of representing the world fully. That is why we make mistakes and why we are regularly surprised. In our heads, we can keep track of only a few variables at one time. We often draw illogical conclusions from accurate assumptions, or logical conclusions from inaccurate assumptions. Most of us, for instance, are surprised by the amount of growth an exponential process can generate. Few of us can intuit how to damp oscillations in a complex system.
3. 然而，反过来说，我们的模型也远不足以全面地代表世界。这就是我们犯错和经常感到惊讶的原因。我们的大脑一次只能记住少数几个变量。我们常常会从准确的假设中得出不合逻辑的结论，或者从不准确的假设中得出合乎逻辑的结论。例如，我们大多数人都会对指数增长过程所能产生的惊人增长感到惊讶。很少有人能够凭直觉判断如何抑制复杂系统中的振荡。
In short, this book is poised on a duality. We know a tremendous amount about how the world works, but not nearly enough. Our knowledge is amazing; our ignorance even more so. We can improve our understanding, but we can’t make it perfect. I believe both sides of this duality, because I have learned much from the study of systems.
简而言之，这本书的核心在于一种二元性。我们对世界的运行方式了解甚多，但远远不够。我们的知识令人惊叹，而我们的无知更是如此。我们可以增进理解，但无法做到完美。我相信这种二元性的两面性，因为我从系统研究中获益良多。
Everything we think we know about the world is a model. Our models do have a strong congruence with the world. Our models fall far short of representing the real world fully.
我们自以为了解的一切关于世界的认知都是一种模型。我们的模型与世界确实有很强的吻合度。但我们的模型远不能完整地展现真实世界。

This chapter describes some of the reasons why dynamic systems are so often surprising. Alternately, it is a compilation of some of the ways our mental models fail to take into account the complications of the real world—at least those ways that one can see from a systems perspective. It is a warning list. Here is where hidden snags lie. You can’t navigate well in an interconnected, feedback-dominated world unless you take your eyes off short-term events and look for long term behavior and structure; unless you are aware of false boundaries and bounded rationality; unless you take into account limiting factors, nonlinearities and delays. You are likely to mistreat, misdesign, or misread systems if you don’t respect their properties of resilience, self-organization, and hierarchy.

本章阐述了动态系统为何常常出人意料的原因。或者说，它汇集了我们思维模型未能充分考虑现实世界复杂性的几种方式——至少从系统视角来看是如此。这是一份警示清单，其中隐藏着诸多陷阱。在一个相互关联、反馈主导的世界中，除非你不再关注短期事件，而是着眼于长期行为和结构；除非你意识到虚假边界和有限理性；除非你考虑到限制因素、非线性关系和延迟，否则你将难以有效应对。如果你不尊重系统的韧性、自组织和层级结构等特性，你很可能会误用、误设计或误读系统。

The bad news, or the good news, depending on your need to control the world and your willingness to be delighted by its surprises, is that even if you do understand all these system characteristics, you may be surprised less often, but you will still be surprised.

坏消息（或者好消息，取决于你是否需要控制世界以及你是否愿意接受世界的惊喜），即使你了解了所有这些系统特征，你受到的惊喜可能会减少，但你仍然会受到惊喜。

Beguiling Events

引人入胜的事件

A system is a big black box
系统就像一个巨大的黑盒子
Of which we can’t unlock the locks,
但我们却无法打开这些锁。
And all we can find out about
我们所能了解到的关于
Is what goes in and what comes out.
就是输入什么和输出什么。
Related by parameters,
通过参数关联，
Permits us, sometimes, to relate
它有时允许我们联系
An input, output and a state.
输入、输出和状态。
If this relation’s good and stable
如果这段关系良好且稳定
Then to predict we may be able,
然后，为了进行预测，我们或许能够……
But if this fails us—heaven forbid!
但如果这失败了——天哪，千万别！
We’ll be compelled to force the lid!
我们将被迫强行打开盖子！

—Kenneth Boulding, 2 economist

——肯尼斯·博尔丁，经济学家

Systems fool us by presenting themselves—or we fool ourselves by seeing the world—as a series of events. The daily news tells of elections, battles, political agreements, disasters, stock market booms or busts. Much of our ordinary conversation is about specific happenings at specific times and places. A team wins. A river floods. The Dow Jones Industrial Average hits 10,000. Oil is discovered. A forest is cut. Events are the outputs, moment by moment, from the black box of the system.

系统会通过伪装成一系列事件来欺骗我们——或者说，我们会通过把世界看作一系列事件来欺骗自己。每日新闻报道选举、战争、政治协议、灾难、股市的繁荣或萧条。我们日常对话的大部分内容都围绕着特定时间地点发生的具体事件。一支球队获胜。一条河流泛滥。道琼斯工业平均指数突破10000点。石油被发现。一片森林被砍伐。这些事件是系统这个“黑匣子”每时每刻的输出。

Events can be spectacular: crashes, assassinations, great victories, terrible tragedies. They hook our emotions. Although we’ve seen many thousands of them on our TV screens or the front page of the paper, each one is different enough from the last to keep us fascinated (just as we never lose our fascination with the chaotic twists and turns of the weather). It’s endlessly engrossing to take in the world as a series of events, and constantly surprising, because that way of seeing the world has almost no predictive or explanatory value. Like the tip of an iceberg rising above the water, events are the most visible aspect of a larger complex—but not always the most important.

事件往往惊心动魄：车祸、暗杀、伟大胜利、惨绝人寰的悲剧。它们牵动着我们的心弦。尽管我们在电视屏幕或报纸头版上已经目睹了成千上万起事件，但每一起事件都与前一起截然不同，足以让我们着迷（正如我们永远不会对变幻莫测的天气失去兴趣一样）。将世界视为一系列事件，这种视角令人着迷，也总是充满惊喜，因为这种看待世界的方式几乎没有任何预测或解释价值。就像冰山一角露出水面一样，事件只是更大复杂体系中最显而易见的部分——但并非总是最重要的。

We are less likely to be surprised if we can see how events accumulate into dynamic patterns of behavior . The team is on a winning streak. The variance of the river is increasing, with higher floodwaters during rains and lower flows during droughts. The Dow has been trending up for two years. Discoveries of oil are becoming less frequent. The felling of forests is happening at an ever-increasing rate.

如果我们能够看到事件如何累积形成动态的行为模式，我们就更不容易感到惊讶。这支球队正处于连胜之中。河流的水位波动性正在增加，雨季洪水水位更高，干旱时期流量更低。道琼斯指数已经连续两年呈上升趋势。石油的发现频率正在降低。森林砍伐的速度正在不断加快。

The behavior of a system is its performance over time—its growth, stagnation, decline, oscillation, randomness, or evolution. If the news did a better job of putting events into historical context, we would have better behavior-level understanding, which is deeper than event-level under standing. When a systems thinker encounters a problem, the first thing he or she does is look for data, time graphs, the history of the system. That’s because long term behavior provides clues to the underlying system structure. And structure is the key to understanding not just what is happening, but why .

系统的行为是指其随时间推移的表现——增长、停滞、衰退、波动、随机性或演化。如果新闻报道能更好地将事件置于历史背景中，我们就能更好地理解行为层面，这比事件层面的理解更为深刻。当系统思考者遇到问题时，首先会寻找数据、时间图表以及系统的历史。这是因为长期行为能够揭示系统的潜在结构。而结构正是理解“发生了什么”以及“为什么会发生”的关键。

The structure of a system is its interlocking stocks, flows, and feedback loops. The diagrams with boxes and arrows (my students call them “spaghetti-and-meatball diagrams”) are pictures of system structure. Structure determines what behaviors are latent in the system. A goal-seeking balancing feedback loop approaches or holds a dynamic equilibrium. A reinforcing feedback loop generates exponential growth. The two of them linked together are capable of growth, decay, or equilibrium. If they also contain delays, they may produce oscillations. If they work in periodic, rapid bursts, they may produce even more surprising behaviors.

系统的结构由其相互交织的存量、流量和反馈回路构成。用方框和箭头表示的图表（我的学生称之为“意大利面条肉丸图”）描绘的是系统结构。结构决定了系统中潜在的行为。一个追求目标的平衡反馈回路会趋近或维持动态平衡。一个增强反馈回路会产生指数增长。两者相互连接，可以实现增长、衰减或达到平衡。如果它们还包含延迟，则可能产生振荡。如果它们以周期性的快速脉冲形式运作，则可能产生更加出人意料的行为。

System structure is the source of system behavior. System behavior reveals itself as a series of events over time.
系统结构是系统行为的根源。系统行为随时间推移表现为一系列事件。

Systems thinking goes back and forth constantly between structure (diagrams of stocks, flows, and feedback) and behavior (time graphs). Systems thinkers strive to understand the connections between the hand releasing the Slinky (event) and the resulting oscillations (behavior) and the mechanical characteristics of the Slinky’s helical coil (structure).

系统思维在结构（存量、流量和反馈图）和行为（时间图）之间不断往复转换。系统思考者致力于理解松开弹簧的手（事件）与由此产生的振荡（行为）以及弹簧螺旋线圈的机械特性（结构）之间的联系。

Simple examples like a Slinky make this event-behavior-structure distinction seem obvious. In fact, much analysis in the world goes no deeper than events. Listen to every night’s explanation of why the stock market did what it did. Stocks went up (down) because the U.S. dollar fell (rose), or the prime interest rate rose (fell), or the Democrats won (lost), or one country invaded another (or didn’t). Event-event analysis.

像弹簧玩具这样简单的例子就能让事件、行为和结构之间的区别显得显而易见。事实上，世界上很多分析都止步于事件本身。听听每天晚上对股市走势的解释吧。股票上涨（下跌）是因为美元贬值（上涨），或者基准利率上升（下降），或者民主党赢了（输了），或者一个国家入侵了另一个国家（或者没有入侵）。这就是事件-事件分析。

These explanations give you no ability to predict what will happen tomorrow. They give you no ability to change the behavior of the system—to make the stock market less volatile or a more reliable indicator of the health of corporations or a better vehicle to encourage investment, for instance.

这些解释并不能让你预测明天会发生什么。它们也无法让你改变系统的运行方式——例如，使股市波动性降低，或使其成为衡量公司健康状况更可靠的指标，或使其成为鼓励投资的更好工具。

Most economic analysis goes one level deeper, to behavior over time. Econometric models strive to find the statistical links among past trends in income, savings, investment, government spending, interest rates, output, or whatever, often in complicated equations.

大多数经济分析会更深入一层，考察行为随时间的变化。计量经济模型力求找到收入、储蓄、投资、政府支出、利率、产出或其他任何指标过去趋势之间的统计联系，而这通常需要用到复杂的方程式。

These behavior-based models are more useful than event-based ones, but they still have fundamental problems. First, they typically overemphasize system flows and underemphasize stocks. Economists follow the behavior of flows, because that’s where the interesting variations and most rapid changes in systems show up. Economic news reports on the national production (flow) of goods and services, the GNP, rather than the total physical capital (stock) of the nation’s factories and farms and businesses that produce those goods and services. But without seeing how stocks affect their related flows through feedback processes, one cannot understand the dynamics of economic systems or the reasons for their behavior.

这些基于行为的模型比基于事件的模型更有用，但它们仍然存在一些根本性问题。首先，它们通常过分强调系统流量而忽视存量。经济学家关注流量的行为，因为系统中最有趣的波动和最快速的变化都体现在流量上。经济新闻报道的是国民生产总值（GNP），即商品和服务的国民生产总值（流量），而不是生产这些商品和服务的工厂、农场和企业的总物质资本（存量）。但是，如果不了解存量如何通过反馈过程影响其相关的流量，就无法理解经济系统的动态变化或其行为背后的原因。

Second, and more seriously, in trying to find statistical links that relate flows to each other, econometricians are searching for something that does not exist. There’s no reason to expect any flow to bear a stable relationship to any other flow. Flows go up and down, on and off, in all sorts of combinations, in response to stocks, not to other flows.

其次，更严重的是，计量经济学家试图寻找流量之间的统计联系，但他们实际上是在寻找并不存在的东西。没有任何理由期望任何流量与其他流量之间存在稳定的关系。流量的波动、增减以及各种组合变化，都是由存量而非其他流量决定的。

Let me use a simple example to explain what I mean. Suppose you knew nothing at all about thermostats, but you had a lot of data about past heat flows into and out of the room. You could find an equation telling you how those flows have varied together in the past, because under ordinary circumstances, being governed by the same stock (temperature of the room), they do vary together.

让我用一个简单的例子来解释我的意思。假设你对恒温器一无所知，但你有很多关于过去房间热量流入和流出的数据。你可以找到一个方程式来告诉你这些热量流在过去是如何同步变化的，因为在通常情况下，由于它们都受同一因素（房间温度）的影响，所以它们确实会同步变化。

Your equation would hold, however, only until something changes in the system’s structure—someone opens a window or improves the insulation, or tunes the furnace, or forgets to order oil. You could predict tomorrow’s room temperature with your equation, as long as the system didn’t change or break down. But if you were asked to make the room warmer, or if the room temperature suddenly started plummeting and you had to fix it, or if you wanted to produce the same room temperature with a lower fuel bill, your behavior-level analysis wouldn’t help you. You would have to dig into the system’s structure.

然而，你的等式只有在系统结构发生变化时才有效——比如有人打开窗户、改善隔热、调整暖气炉，或者忘记订购燃油。只要系统不发生变化或发生故障，你就可以利用你的等式预测明天的室温。但是，如果你被要求提高房间温度，或者房间温度突然骤降需要你采取措施，又或者你想在保持相同室温的同时降低燃料费用，那么你的行为层面分析就无济于事了。你必须深入研究系统的结构。

That’s why behavior-based econometric models are pretty good at predicting the near-term performance of the economy, quite bad at predicting the longer-term performance, and terrible at telling one how to improve the performance of the economy.

这就是为什么基于行为的计量经济模型在预测经济的近期表现方面相当不错，在预测长期表现方面相当糟糕，而且在告诉人们如何改善经济表现方面更是糟糕透顶。

And that’s one reason why systems of all kinds surprise us. We are too fascinated by the events they generate. We pay too little attention to their history. And we are insufficiently skilled at seeing in their history clues to the structures from which behavior and events flow.

这就是为什么各种系统总能给我们带来惊喜的原因之一。我们太着迷于它们所产生的事件，却忽略了它们的历史。我们又缺乏足够的技巧，无法从它们的历史中发现行为和事件背后的结构线索。

Linear Minds in a Nonlinear World

非线性世界中的线性思维

Linear relationships are easy to think about: the more the merrier. Linear equations are solvable, which makes them suitable for textbooks. Linear systems have an important modular virtue: you can take them apart and put them together again—the pieces add up.
线性关系很容易理解：越多越好。线性方程组是可解的，因此很适合用于教科书。线性系统具有重要的模块化特性：你可以将其拆解并重新组合——各个部分可以合并。
Nonlinear systems generally cannot be solved and cannot be added together. . . . Nonlinearity means that the act of playing the game has a way of changing the rules. . . . That twisted changeability makes nonlinearity hard to calculate, but it also creates rich kinds of behavior that never occur in linear systems.
非线性系统通常无法求解，也无法相加……非线性意味着游戏规则会随着游戏进程而改变……这种复杂的变幻莫测使得非线性难以计算，但也造就了线性系统中从未出现过的丰富行为。
—James Gleick, author of Chaos: Making a New Science 3
——詹姆斯·格雷克，《混沌：创造一门新科学》的作者 3

We often are not very skilled in understanding the nature of relationships. A linear relationship between two elements in a system can be drawn on a graph with a straight line. It’s a relationship with constant proportions. If I put 10 pounds of fertilizer on my field, my yield will go up by 2 bushels. If I put on 20 pounds, my yield will go up by 4 bushels. If I put on 30 pounds, I’ll get an increase of 6 bushels.

我们往往不太擅长理解关系的本质。系统中两个要素之间的线性关系可以用图表上的直线表示。这种关系具有恒定的比例。如果我在田里施10磅肥料，产量会增加2蒲式耳。如果我施20磅，产量会增加4蒲式耳。如果我施30磅，产量会增加6蒲式耳。

A nonlinear relationship is one in which the cause does not produce a proportional effect. The relationship between cause and effect can only be drawn with curves or wiggles, not with a straight line. If I put 100 pounds of fertilizer on, my yield will go up by 10 bushels; if I put on 200, my yield will not go up at all; if I put on 300, my yield will go down. Why? I’ve damaged my soil with “too much of a good thing.”

非线性关系是指原因与结果并非成比例的关系。原因和结果之间的关系只能用曲线或折线来表示，而不能用直线来表示。如果我施100磅肥料，产量会增加10蒲式耳；如果我施200磅，产量不会增加；如果我施300磅，产量反而会下降。为什么？因为我“过犹不及”，破坏了土壤。

The world is full of nonlinearities.

世界充满了非线性因素。

So the world often surprises our linear-thinking minds. If we’ve learned that a small push produces a small response, we think that twice as big a push will produce twice as big a response. But in a nonlinear system, twice the push could produce one-sixth the response, or the response squared, or no response at all.

所以，世界常常会出乎我们线性思维的意料。如果我们已经知道，轻微的推动会产生轻微的回应，我们就会认为，推动力度加倍也会产生加倍的回应。但在非线性系统中，加倍的推动可能只会产生六分之一的回应，也可能只会产生回应的平方，甚至可能根本没有回应。

Here are some examples of nonlinearities:

以下是一些非线性的例子：

• As the flow of traffic on a highway increases, car speed is affected only slightly over a large range of car density. Eventually, however, small further increases in density produce a rapid drop-off in speed. And when the number of cars on the highway builds up to a certain point, it can result in a traffic jam, and car speed drops to zero.
• 随着高速公路车流量的增加，在较大的车辆密度范围内，车速变化不大。然而，最终，即使车辆密度略有增加，车速也会迅速下降。当高速公路上的车辆数量达到一定程度时，就会造成交通拥堵，车速甚至会降至零。
• Soil erosion can proceed for a long time without much affect on crop yield—until the topsoil is worn down to the depth of the root zone of the crop. Beyond that point, a little further erosion can cause yields to plummet.
• 土壤侵蚀可能持续很长时间，对作物产量影响不大——直到表层土壤被侵蚀到作物根系所在的深度。超过这个深度后，即使侵蚀程度稍有增加，也会导致产量骤降。
• A little tasteful advertising can awaken interest in a product. A lot of blatant advertising can cause disgust for the product.
适度的广告可以激发人们对产品的兴趣，而过多的低俗广告则会让人对产品产生反感。

You can see why nonlinearities produce surprises. They foil the reasonable expectation that if a little of some cure did a little good, then a lot of it will do a lot of good—or alternately that if a little destructive action caused only a tolerable amount of harm, then more of that same kind of destruction will cause only a bit more harm. Reasonable expectations like these in a nonlinear world produce classic mistakes.

你就能明白为什么非线性会带来意想不到的结果。它们会打破人们的合理预期：如果少量某种疗法能带来少量益处，那么大量使用也会带来大量益处；或者反过来说，如果少量破坏性行为只会造成可容忍的伤害，那么更多同类破坏性行为只会造成略微更大的伤害。在非线性世界中，诸如此类的合理预期会导致经典的错误。

Nonlinearities are important not only because they confound our expectations about the relationship between action and response. They are even more important because they change the relative strengths of feedback loops . They can flip a system from one mode of behavior to another.

非线性之所以重要，不仅在于它们会颠覆我们对行动与反应之间关系的预期，更重要的是，它们会改变反馈回路的相对强度，甚至能使系统从一种行为模式转变为另一种。

Nonlinearities are the chief cause of the shifting dominance that characterizes several of the systems in the zoo—the sudden swing between exponential growth caused by a dominant reinforcing loop, say, and then decline caused by a suddenly dominant balancing loop.

非线性是动物园中几个系统的主要特征——主导地位的转变——的主要原因。例如，由主导的增强回路引起的指数增长，然后由突然占主导地位的平衡回路引起的衰退，都是由非线性引起的。

To take a dramatic example of the effects of nonlinearities, consider the destructive irruptions of the spruce budworm in North American forests.

举一个非线性效应的极端例子，考虑一下北美森林中云杉芽虫的破坏性爆发。

INTERLUDE • Spruce Budworms, Firs, and Pesticides

插曲 • 云杉芽虫、冷杉和杀虫剂

Tree ring records show that the spruce budworm has been killing spruce and fir trees periodically in North America for at least 400 years. Until this century, no one much cared. The valuable tree for the lumber industry was the white pine. Spruce and fir were considered “weed species.” Eventually, however, the stands of virgin pine were gone, and the lumber industry turned to spruce and fir. Suddenly the budworm was seen as a serious pest.

树轮记录显示，云杉芽虫在北美至少400年来一直周期性地危害云杉和冷杉。直到本世纪，人们对此并不十分在意。当时，木材工业的主要树种是白松，云杉和冷杉则被视为“杂草”。然而，随着原始白松林的消失，木材工业逐渐转向云杉和冷杉。突然间，云杉芽虫被视为一种严重的害虫。

So, beginning in the 1950s, northern forests were sprayed with DDT to control the spruce budworm. In spite of the spraying, every year there was a budworm resurgence. Annual sprays were continued through the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, until DDT was banned. Then the sprays were changed to fenitrothion, acephate, Sevin, and methoxychlor.

因此，从20世纪50年代开始，北方森林开始喷洒DDT来控制云杉芽虫。尽管喷洒了DDT，但每年云杉芽虫都会卷土重来。这种年度喷洒一直持续到20世纪50年代、60年代和70年代，直到DDT被禁用。之后，喷洒的杀虫剂改为倍硫磷、乙酰甲胺磷、西维因和甲氧滴滴涕。

Insecticides were no longer thought to be the ultimate answer to the budworm problem, but they were still seen as essential. “Insecticides buy time,” said one forester, “That’s all the forest manager wants; to preserve the trees until the mill is ready for them.”

人们不再认为杀虫剂是解决芽虫问题的最终方案，但它们仍然被视为必不可少的。“杀虫剂能争取时间，”一位林业员说，“这正是森林管理者所希望的：保护树木，直到锯木厂准备好接收它们。”

By 1980, spraying costs were getting unmanageable—the Canadian province of New Brunswick spent $12.5 million on budworm “control” that year. Concerned citizens were objecting to the drenching of the landscape with poisons. And, in spite of the sprays, the budworm was still killing as many as 20 million hectares (50 million acres) of trees per year.

到1980年，喷洒农药的成本已经难以控制——加拿大新不伦瑞克省当年在防治卷叶蛾方面花费了1250万美元。忧心忡忡的民众反对用毒药浸透大地。尽管喷洒了农药，卷叶蛾每年仍然会杀死多达2000万公顷（5000万英亩）的树木。

C. S. Holling of the University of British Columbia and Gordon Baskerville of the University of New Brunswick put together a computer model to get a whole-system look at the budworm problem. They discovered that before the spraying began, the budworm had been barely detectable in most years. It was controlled by a number of predators, including birds, a spider, a parasitic wasp, and several diseases. Every few decades, however, there was a budworm outbreak, lasting from six to ten years. Then the budworm population would subside, eventually to explode again

不列颠哥伦比亚大学的C. S. Holling和新不伦瑞克大学的Gordon Baskerville建立了一个计算机模型，从系统层面分析了云杉芽虫问题。他们发现，在喷洒农药之前，云杉芽虫在大多数年份都几乎难以察觉。包括鸟类、蜘蛛、寄生蜂和几种疾病在内的多种天敌控制着云杉芽虫的数量。然而，每隔几十年，云杉芽虫就会爆发一次，持续六到十年。之后，云杉芽虫的数量会下降，但最终又会再次爆发。

The budworm preferentially attacks balsam fir, secondarily spruce. Balsam fir is the most competitive tree in the northern forest. Left to its own devices, it would crowd out spruce and birch, and the forest would become a monoculture of nothing but fir. Each budworm outbreak cuts back the fir population, opening the forest for spruce and birch. Eventually fir moves back in.

芽虫主要侵袭香脂冷杉，其次是云杉。香脂冷杉是北方森林中最具竞争力的树种。如果任其自然发展，它会排挤云杉和桦树，最终森林将变成单一的冷杉林。每次芽虫爆发都会减少冷杉的数量，为云杉和桦树腾出生长空间。最终，冷杉会重新占据森林。

As the fir population builds up, the probability of an outbreak increases— nonlinearly . The reproductive potential of the budworm increases more than proportionately to the availability of its favorite food supply. The final trigger is two or three warm, dry springs, perfect for the survival of budworm larvae. (If you’re doing event-level analysis, you will blame the outburst on the warm, dry springs.)

随着冷杉种群数量的增加，虫害爆发的概率也随之增加——但这种增加并非线性。冷杉芽虫的繁殖潜力增长速度远超其喜爱的食物供应量。最终的触发因素是连续两到三个温暖干燥的春天，这种气候条件非常适宜冷杉芽虫幼虫的生存。（如果你进行的是事件层面的分析，你会将虫害爆发归咎于温暖干燥的春天。）

The budworm population grows too great for its natural enemies to hold in check— nonlinearly . Over a wide range of conditions, greater budworm populations result in more rapid multiplication of budworm predators. But beyond some point, the predators can multiply no faster. What was a reinforcing relationship—more budworms, faster predator multiplication—becomes a nonrelationship—more budworms, no faster predator multiplication—and the budworms take off, unimpeded.

芽虫种群数量增长过快，超出了天敌的控制能力——这种增长并非线性。在多种条件下，芽虫种群数量的增加会导致其天敌数量迅速增长。但超过某个临界点后，天敌的繁殖速度将不再更快。原本的正相关关系——芽虫数量越多，天敌繁殖速度越快——转变为负相关关系——芽虫数量越多，天敌繁殖速度却不再加快——芽虫得以不受阻碍地迅速繁殖。

Now only one thing can stop the outbreak: the insect reducing its own food supply by killing off fir trees. When that finally happens, the budworm population crashes— nonlinearly . The reinforcing loop of budworm reproduction yields dominance to the balancing loop of budworm starvation. Spruce and birch move into the spaces where the firs used to be, and the cycle begins again.

现在只有一件事能阻止虫害爆发：昆虫通过啃食冷杉树来减少自身的食物来源。当这种情况最终发生时，卷叶蛾的数量会骤减——但并非呈线性下降。卷叶蛾繁殖的增强循环让位于卷叶蛾饥饿的平衡循环。云杉和桦树会占据冷杉树曾经生长的空间，然后循环再次开始。

The budworm/spruce/fir system oscillates over decades, but it is ecologically stable within bounds. It can go on forever. The main effect of the budworm is to allow tree species other than fir to persist. But in this case what is ecologically stable is economically unstable. In eastern Canada, the economy is almost completely dependent on the logging industry, which is dependent on a steady supply of fir and spruce.

芽虫/云杉/冷杉生态系统以数十年为周期波动，但在一定范围内具有生态稳定性，可以无限期地持续下去。芽虫的主要作用是使冷杉以外的其他树种得以生存。但在这种情况下，生态稳定却意味着经济不稳定。在加拿大东部，经济几乎完全依赖于伐木业，而伐木业又依赖于稳定的冷杉和云杉供应。

Many relationships in systems are nonlinear. Their relative strengths shift in disproportionate amounts as the stocks in the system shift. Nonlinearities in feedback systems produce shifting dominance of loops and many complexities in system behavior.
系统中许多关系都是非线性的。随着系统中资源的变化，这些关系的相对强度也会发生不成比例的变化。反馈系统中的非线性会导致回路主导地位的转移，并使系统行为变得复杂。

When industry sprays insecticides, it shifts the whole system to balance uneasily on different points within its nonlinear relationships. It kills off not only the pest, but the natural enemies of the pest, thereby weakening the feedback loop that normally keeps the budworms in check. It keeps the density of fir high, moving the budworms up their nonlinear reproduction curve to the point at which they’re perpetually on the edge of population explosion.

当工业喷洒杀虫剂时，整个系统会在其非线性关系的不同点上发生不稳定的平衡。它不仅杀死害虫，也杀死害虫的天敌，从而削弱了通常控制云杉芽虫数量的反馈回路。它使云杉的密度保持在高位，推动云杉芽虫沿着其非线性繁殖曲线向上攀升，直至其种群数量始终处于爆发式增长的边缘。

The forest management practices have set up what Holling calls “persistent semi-outbreak conditions” over larger and larger areas. The managers have found themselves locked into a policy in which there is an incipient volcano bubbling, such that, if the policy fails, there will be an outbreak of an intensity that has never been seen before.” 4

森林管理措施已在越来越大的区域内造成了霍林所说的“持续的半爆发状态”。管理者发现自己陷入了一种政策困境，这种政策就像一座即将喷发的火山，一旦政策失败，将会爆发前所未有的严重灾害。

Nonexistent Boundaries

不存在的边界

When we think in terms of systems, we see that a fundamental misconception is embedded in the popular term “side-effects.”. . . This phrase means roughly “effects which I hadn’t foreseen or don’t want to think about.”. . . Side-effects no more deserve the adjective “side” than does the “principal” effect. It is hard to think in terms of systems, and we eagerly warp our language to protect ourselves from the necessity of doing so.
当我们从系统的角度思考问题时，会发现“副作用”这个常用词中蕴含着一个根本性的误解……这个词大致意思是“我没有预料到或不想考虑的影响”……副作用和“主要”效应一样，都不应该被冠以“副作用”这个形容词。从系统的角度思考问题并非易事，因此我们往往会扭曲语言，以逃避这种思考方式带来的挑战。

—Garrett Hardin, 5 ecologist

——加勒特·哈丁，生态学家

Remember the clouds in the structural diagrams of Chapters One and Two? Beware of clouds! They are prime sources of system surprises.

还记得第一章和第二章结构图中的云吗？小心云！它们是系统出现意外情况的主要来源。

Clouds stand for the beginnings and ends of flows. They are stocks—sources and sinks—that are being ignored at the moment for the purposes of simplifying the present discussion. They mark the boundary of the system diagram. They rarely mark a real boundary, because systems rarely have real boundaries. Everything, as they say, is connected to everything else, and not neatly. There is no clearly determinable boundary between the sea and the land, between sociology and anthropology, between an automobile’s exhaust and your nose. There are only boundaries of word, thought, perception, and social agreement—artificial, mental-model boundaries.

云朵象征着流动的起点和终点。它们是存量——源和汇——为了简化当前的讨论，我们暂时忽略了它们。它们标志着系统图的边界。但它们很少标志着真正的边界，因为系统本身很少有真正的边界。正如人们常说的，万物皆有联系，而且这种联系并非泾渭分明。海洋与陆地之间、社会学与人类学之间、汽车尾气与你的鼻子之间，都没有清晰可辨的边界。存在的边界只有语言、思想、感知和社会共识——人为的、心智模型式的边界。

The greatest complexities arise exactly at boundaries. There are Czechs on the German side of the border and Germans on the Czech side of the border. Forest species extend beyond the edge of the forest into the field; field species penetrate partway into the forest. Disorderly, mixed-up borders are sources of diversity and creativity.

最复杂的情况往往出现在边界处。德国一侧有捷克人，捷克一侧也有德国人。森林物种会延伸到森林边缘之外的田野；田野物种则会部分侵入森林。这种杂乱无章、错综复杂的边界反而孕育了多样性和创造力。

In our system zoo, for instance, I showed the flow of cars into a car dealer’s inventory as coming from a cloud. Of course, cars don’t come from a cloud, they come from the transformation of a stock of raw materials, with the help of capital, labor, energy, technology, and management (the means of production). Similarly, the flow of cars out of the inventory goes not to a cloud, but through sales to the households or businesses of consumers.

例如，在我们的系统模型中，我将汽车流入经销商库存的过程展示为来自云端。当然，汽车并非来自云端，而是通过资本、劳动力、能源、技术和管理（生产资料）等手段，将原材料转化为成品。同样，汽车从库存流出的过程也不是进入云端，而是通过销售给消费者的家庭或企业。

Whether it is important to keep track of raw materials or consumers’ home stocks (whether it is legitimate to replace them in a diagram with clouds) depends on whether these stocks are likely to have a significant influence on the behavior of the system over the time period of interest. If raw materials are guaranteed to be abundant and consumers continue to demand the products, then clouds will do. But if there could be a materials shortage or a product glut, and if we drew a mental boundary around the system that did not include these stocks, then we could be surprised by future events.

是否需要追踪原材料或消费者的家庭库存（以及是否可以用云图代替它们）取决于这些库存是否会对目标时间段内的系统行为产生显著影响。如果原材料供应充足且消费者需求持续，那么用云图表示即可。但如果可能出现原材料短缺或产品过剩，而我们事先设定的系统边界并未包含这些库存，那么未来的事件可能会让我们措手不及。

Figure 47. Revealing some of the stocks behind the clouds.

图 47. 揭开云层背后的部分股票。

There are still clouds in Figure 47. The boundary can be expanded further. Processed raw materials come from chemical plants, smelters, or refineries, whose input comes, ultimately, from the earth. Processing creates not only products, but also employment, wages, profits, and pollution. Discarded consumers’ stocks go to landfills or incinerators or recycling centers, from which they go on to have further effects on society and the environment. Landfills leach into drinking-water wells, incinerators produce smoke and ash, recycling centers move materials back into the production stream.

图 47 中仍有云层。边界可以进一步扩展。加工后的原材料来自化工厂、冶炼厂或炼油厂，而这些工厂的原料最终都来自地球。加工过程不仅创造产品，还创造就业、工资、利润，但也造成污染。消费者丢弃的库存最终被送往垃圾填埋场、焚烧炉或回收中心，进而对社会和环境产生进一步的影响。垃圾填埋场的渗滤液会渗入饮用水井，焚烧炉会产生烟雾和灰烬，回收中心则将材料重新投入生产流程。

Whether it’s important to think about the full flow from mine to dump, or as industry calls it, “from cradle to grave,” depends on who wants to know, for what purpose, over how long. In the long term, the full flow is important and, as the physical economy grows and society’s “ecological footprint” expands, the long term is increasingly coming to be the short term. Landfills fill up with a suddenness that has been surprising for people whose mental models picture garbage as going “away,” into some sort of a cloud. Sources of raw materials—mines, wells, and oil fields—can be exhausted with surprising suddenness too.

是否应该考虑从矿山到垃圾填埋场的完整流程，或者如业内所称的“从摇篮到坟墓”，取决于谁想了解、出于什么目的以及需要关注多长时间。从长远来看，完整流程至关重要；随着实体经济的增长和社会“生态足迹”的扩大，长远目标正日益成为短期目标。垃圾填埋场的填满速度之快，令那些习惯于将垃圾“消失”成某种云雾的人们感到惊讶。原材料来源——矿山、油井和油田——的枯竭速度也同样惊人。

With a long enough time horizon, even mines and dumps are not the end of the story. The great geological cycles of the earth keep moving materials around, opening and closing seas, raising up and wearing down mountains. Eons from now, everything put in a dump will end up on the top of a mountain or deep under the sea. New deposits of metals and fuels will form. On planet Earth there are no system “clouds,” no ultimate boundaries. Even real clouds in the sky are part of a hydrological cycle. Everything physical comes from somewhere, everything goes somewhere, everything keeps moving.

从足够长的时间尺度来看，即使是矿山和垃圾场也并非故事的终点。地球伟大的地质循环不断地搬运物质，海洋的开合，山脉的隆起与消融。亿万年后，所有被倾倒在垃圾场的物质最终都会堆积在山顶或沉入海底。新的金属和燃料矿藏将会形成。地球上没有所谓的“云”，没有绝对的边界。即使是天空中的云，也是水循环的一部分。一切物质都来自某个地方，最终都会去往某个地方，一切都在不断运动。

Which is not to say that every model, mental or computer, has to follow each connection until it includes the whole planet. Clouds are a necessary part of models that describe metaphysical flows. Anger literally “comes out of a cloud,” as does love, hatred, self esteem, and so on. If we’re to understand anything, we have to simplify, which means we have to make boundaries. Often that’s a safe thing to do. It’s usually not a problem, for example, to think of populations with births and deaths coming from and going to clouds, as in Figure 48.

但这并不意味着每个模型，无论是心理模型还是计算机模型，都必须追踪每一个连接，直到涵盖整个星球。云是描述形而上学流动的模型中不可或缺的一部分。愤怒的确“源于云”，爱、恨、自尊等等也是如此。如果我们想要理解任何事物，就必须进行简化，这意味着我们必须划定界限。通常情况下，这样做是安全的。例如，如图 48 所示，将人口的出生和死亡视为源于云又归于云，通常不会造成问题。

Figure 48. More clouds.

图 48. 更多云层。

Figure 48 shows actual “cradle to grave” boundaries. Even these boundaries would be unserviceable, however, if the population in question experienced significant in- or out-migration, or if the problem under discussion was limited cemetery space.

图 48 显示了实际的“从摇篮到坟墓”的边界。然而，即使是这些边界，如果相关人口经历了显著的迁入或迁出，或者如果讨论的问题是墓地空间有限，也无法适用。

The lesson of boundaries is hard even for systems thinkers to get. There is no single, legitimate boundary to draw around a system. We have to invent boundaries for clarity and sanity; and boundaries can produce problems when we forget that we’ve artificially created them.

即使对于系统思考者来说，理解边界的概念也并非易事。并不存在一个适用于所有系统的、唯一合理的边界。为了清晰和理智，我们必须人为地设定边界；而当我们忘记这些边界是人为创造的时，它们反而会带来问题。

There are no separate systems. The world is a continuum. Where to draw a boundary around a system depends on the purpose of the discussion —the questions we want to ask.
世界并非由彼此分离的系统构成，而是一个连续体。如何界定一个系统的边界，取决于讨论的目的——我们想要提出的问题。

When you draw boundaries too narrowly, the system surprises you. For example, if you try to deal with urban traffic problems without thinking about settlement patterns, you build highways, which attract housing developments along their whole length. Those households, in turn, put more cars on the highways, which then become just as clogged as before.

当你把边界划得太窄时，系统会给你意想不到的结果。例如，如果你在解决城市交通问题时不考虑居民区布局，你修建的高速公路会吸引沿线住宅区不断开发。而这些住宅区反过来又会增加高速公路的车辆，导致高速公路最终和以前一样拥堵。

If you try to solve a sewage problem by throwing the waste into a river, the towns downstream make it clear that the boundary for thinking about sewage has to include the whole river. It might also have to include the soil groundwater surrounding the river. It probably doesn’t have to include the next watershed or the planetary hydrological cycle.

如果你试图通过把污水直接排入河流来解决污水问题，下游城镇会明确地告诉你，污水处理的边界必须涵盖整条河流。它可能还必须包括河流周围的土壤和地下水。但可能不必包括下一个流域或全球水文循环。

Planning for a national park used to stop at the physical boundary of the park. But park boundaries around the world are regularly crossed by nomadic peoples, by migrating wildlife, by waters that flow into, out of, or under the park, by the effects of economic development at the park’s edges, by acid rain, and now by a climate changing from greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Even without climate change, to manage a park you have to think about a boundary wider than the official perimeter.

过去，国家公园的规划仅限于公园的实际边界。但世界各地的公园边界经常受到游牧民族、迁徙野生动物、流入、流出或流经公园的水流、公园边缘经济发展的影响、酸雨以及如今大气中温室气体导致的气候变化的影响。即使没有气候变化，管理一个公园也必须考虑比官方边界更广阔的边界。

Systems analysts often fall into the opposite trap: making boundaries too large. They have a habit of producing diagrams that cover several pages with small print and many arrows connecting everything with everything. There is the system! they say. If you have considered anything less, you are academically illegitimate.

系统分析师常常会陷入另一个陷阱：把边界划得太宽。他们习惯于绘制占据好几页纸、字迹很小、箭头密密麻麻的图表，把所有东西都连接起来。他们说：“这就是系统！” 如果你考虑的范围比这小，那你的学术水平就不合格。

This “my model is bigger than your model” game results in enormously complicated analyses, which produce piles of information that may only serve to obscure the answers to the questions at hand. For example, modeling the earth’s climate in full detail is interesting for many reasons, but may not be necessary for figuring out how to reduce a country’s CO2 emissions to reduce climate change.

这种“我的模型比你的模型更大”的博弈会导致极其复杂的分析，产生大量信息，而这些信息可能只会掩盖当前问题的答案。例如，对地球气候进行全面细致的建模固然有很多好处，但对于弄清楚如何减少一个国家的二氧化碳排放以减缓气候变化而言，这可能并非必要。

The right boundary for thinking about a problem rarely coincides with the boundary of an academic discipline, or with a political boundary. Rivers make handy borders between countries, but the worst possible borders for managing the quantity and quality of the water. Air is worse than water in its insistence on crossing political borders. National boundaries mean nothing when it comes to ozone depletion in the stratosphere, or greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, or ocean dumping.

思考问题的正确边界很少与学科边界或政治边界重合。河流是国界线，但却是管理水量和水质最糟糕的边界。空气比水更甚，它执意跨越政治边界。在平流层臭氧损耗、大气温室气体排放或海洋倾倒等问题上，国界毫无意义。

Ideally, we would have the mental flexibility to find the appropriate boundary for thinking about each new problem. We are rarely that flexible. We get attached to the boundaries our minds happen to be accustomed to. Think how many arguments have to do with boundaries—national boundaries, trade boundaries, ethnic boundaries, boundaries between public and private responsibility, and boundaries between the rich and the poor, polluters and pollutees, people alive now and people who will come in the future. Universities can maintain disputes for years about the boundaries between economics and government, art and art history, literature and literary criticism. Too often, universities are living monuments to boundary rigidity.

理想情况下，我们应该具备足够的思维灵活性，为思考每一个新问题找到合适的界限。然而，我们很少能做到这一点。我们往往会固守那些我们思维习惯的界限。想想有多少争论都与界限有关——国界、贸易边界、种族边界、公私责任的界限、贫富差距、污染者和被污染者之间的界限、当代人和未来人的界限。大学里，关于经济与政府、艺术与艺术史、文学与文学批评之间的界限，争论往往旷日持久。太多时候，大学本身就是界限僵化的活生生的纪念碑。

Figure 49. Examples of more clouds. These are systems in which a boundary or cloud should not stop you from thinking beyond the borders of the system, but start you thinking beyond those borders. What is driving the supply of people being given new sentences? Where do the fuel rods go after replacement? What happens to an unemployed person whose registration for unemployment lapses?

图 49. 更多云状图示例。在这些系统中，边界或云状图不应阻止你思考系统边界之外的问题，而应引导你思考这些边界之外的问题。是什么因素导致越来越多的人被判处新的刑罚？燃料棒更换后会去哪里？失业登记失效的失业人员会面临什么？

It’s a great art to remember that boundaries are of our own making, and that they can and should be reconsidered for each new discussion, problem, or purpose . It’s a challenge to stay creative enough to drop the boundaries that worked for the last problem and to find the most appropriate set of boundaries for the next question. It’s also a necessity, if problems are to be solved well.

记住界限是我们自己设定的，并且应该针对每一个新的讨论、问题或目标重新审视这些界限，这是一门高深的艺术。保持足够的创造力，舍弃那些曾经适用于上一个问题的界限，并为下一个问题找到最合适的界限，这本身就是一种挑战。但如果想要妥善解决问题，这也是必不可少的。

Layers of Limits

层层限制

Systems surprise us because our minds like to think about single causes neatly producing single effects. We like to think about one or at most a few things at a time. And we don’t like, especially when our own plans and desires are involved, to think about limits.

系统常常让我们感到意外，因为我们的思维习惯于将单一原因与单一结果联系起来。我们喜欢一次只考虑一件事，或者最多几件事。而且，尤其当涉及到我们自身的计划和欲望时，我们更不愿意去思考限制。

But we live in a world in which many causes routinely come together to produce many effects. Multiple inputs produce multiple outputs, and virtually all of the inputs, and therefore outputs, are limited. For example, an industrial manufacturing process needs:

但我们生活在一个众多因素共同作用产生多种结果的世界。多种投入产生多种产出，而几乎所有投入，以及产出，都是有限的。例如，一个工业制造过程需要：

• capital
• 首都
• labor
• 劳动
• energy
• 活力
• raw materials
• 原料
• land
• 土地
• water
• 水
• technology
• 技术
• credit
• 信用
• insurance
• 保险
• customers
• 顾客
• good management
• 良好的管理
• public-funded infrastructure and government services (such as police and fire protection and education for managers and workers)
• 公共资金支持的基础设施和政府服务（例如警察和消防保护以及管理人员和工人的培训）
• functioning families to bring up and care for both producers and consumers
• 健全的家庭能够养育和照顾生产者和消费者
• a healthy ecosystem to supply or support all these inputs and to absorb or carry away their wastes
• 一个健康的生态系统，能够提供或支持所有这些投入，并吸收或带走它们的废物。

A patch of growing grain needs:

一片正在生长的谷物需要：

• sunlight
阳光
• air
• 空气
• water
• 水
• nitrogen
• 氮
• phosphorus
磷
• potassium
• 钾
• dozens of minor nutrients
•数十种微量营养素
• a friable soil and the services of a microbial soil community
• 疏松的土壤和土壤微生物群落的服务
• some system to control weeds and pests
• 一些控制杂草和害虫的系统
• protection from the wastes of the industrial manufacturer
• 防止受到工业制造商废弃物的侵害

It was with regard to grain that Justus von Liebig came up with his famous “law of the minimum.” It doesn’t matter how much nitrogen is available to the grain, he said, if what’s short is phosphorus. It does no good to pour on more phosphorus, if the problem is low potassium.

尤斯图斯·冯·李比希正是针对谷物提出了他著名的“最低限度定律”。他指出，如果谷物缺乏的是磷，那么无论氮肥多少都无济于事；同样，如果问题是钾肥不足，那么大量施用磷肥也无济于事。

Bread will not rise without yeast, no matter how much flour it has. Children will not thrive without protein, no matter how many carbohydrates they eat. Companies can’t keep going without energy, no matter how many customers they have—or without customers, no matter how much energy they have.

没有酵母，面包发不起来，不管面粉放多少。没有蛋白质，孩子就无法健康成长，不管碳水化合物吃多少。没有能源，公司就无法运转，不管客户有多少；没有客户，公司就无法运转，不管能源多么充裕。

This concept of a limiting factor is simple and widely misunderstood. Agronomists assume, for example, that they know what to put in artificial fertilizer, because they have identified many of the major and minor nutrients in good soil. Are there any essential nutrients they have not identified? How do artificial fertilizers affect soil microbe communities? Do they interfere with, and therefore limit, any other functions of good soil? And what limits the production of artificial fertilizers?

限制因素的概念虽然简单，却常常被误解。例如，农学家们认为他们知道应该在化肥中添加什么，因为他们已经确定了优质土壤中的许多主要和次要营养元素。那么，是否存在他们尚未发现的必需营养元素？化肥如何影响土壤微生物群落？它们是否会干扰并因此限制优质土壤的其他功能？又是什么限制了化肥的生产？

At any given time, the input that is most important to a system is the one that is most limiting.
在任何特定时刻，对系统而言最重要的输入往往也是限制性最强的输入。

Rich countries transfer capital or technology to poor ones and wonder why the economies of the receiving countries still don’t develop, never thinking that capital or technology may not be the most limiting factors.

富裕国家向贫穷国家转移资本或技术，然后纳闷为什么接受国的经济仍然没有发展，却从未想过资本或技术可能并非最主要的限制因素。

Economics evolved in a time when labor and capital were the most common limiting factors to production. Therefore, most economic production functions keep track only of these two factors (and sometimes technology). As the economy grows relative to the ecosystem, however, and the limiting factors shift to clean water, clean air, dump space, and acceptable forms of energy and raw materials, the traditional focus on only capital and labor becomes increasingly unhelpful.

经济学发展于劳动力和资本是生产最常见限制因素的时代。因此，大多数经济生产函数只关注这两个因素（有时也包括技术）。然而，随着经济相对于生态系统的增长，限制因素逐渐转变为清洁的水源、清洁的空气、垃圾填埋场以及可接受的能源和原材料形式，传统的仅关注资本和劳动力的做法就变得越来越不适用。

One of the classic models taught to systems students at MIT is Jay Forrester’s corporate-growth model. It starts with a successful young company, growing rapidly. The problem for this company is to recognize deal with its shifting limits—limits that change in response to the company’s own growth.

麻省理工学院系统工程专业的学生学习的经典模型之一是杰伊·福雷斯特的企业增长模型。该模型以一家快速发展且成功的初创公司为起点。这家公司面临的问题是如何识别并应对其不断变化的限制——这些限制会随着公司自身的增长而改变。

The company may hire salespeople, for example, who are so good that they generate orders faster than the factory can produce. Delivery delays increase and customers are lost, because production capacity is the most limiting factor. So the managers expand the capital stock of production plants. New people are hired in a hurry and trained too little. Quality suffers and customers are lost because labor skill is the most limiting factor. So management invests in worker training. Quality improves, new orders pour in, and the order-fulfillment and record-keeping system clogs. And so forth.

例如，公司可能会雇佣一些销售人员，他们的业绩非常出色，以至于订单量超过了工厂的生产能力。由于产能成为最大的限制因素，交货延迟增加，客户流失。于是，管理层扩大了生产工厂的资本规模。新员工被匆忙招聘，但培训不足。由于劳动力技能成为最大的限制因素，产品质量下降，客户流失。于是，管理层投资于员工培训。产品质量提高了，新订单纷至沓来，但订单履行和记录系统却不堪重负。如此循环往复。

There are layers of limits around every growing plant, child, epidemic, new product, technological advance, company, city, economy, and population.
