Gift-giving cultures redistribute wealth through potlatches and other ceremonies that increase the social standing of the gift giver.

有很多方法可以打破富者愈富、贫者愈贫的恶性循环：例如，制定（几乎无懈可击的）税法，对富人征收比穷人更高的税率；慈善事业；公共福利；工会；全民平等的医疗和教育；以及遗产税（让每一代人都能重新开始财富分配）。大多数工业化社会都采取了类似的制衡措施，以打破“成功者陷阱”，确保每个人都能参与其中。而馈赠文化则通过宴饮和其他仪式来重新分配财富，这些仪式也能提升馈赠者的社会地位。

These equalizing mechanisms may derive from simple morality, or they may come from the practical understanding that losers, if they are unable to get out of the game of success to the successful, and if they have no hope of winning, could get frustrated enough to destroy the playing field.

这些平衡机制可能源于简单的道德观念，也可能源于这样一种实际的理解：失败者如果无法从与成功者的竞争中脱颖而出，并且没有获胜的希望，就可能因为沮丧而破坏竞争环境。

THE TRAP: SUCCESS TO THE SUCCESSFUL
陷阱：成功者的成功
If the winners of a competition are systematically rewarded with the means to win again, a reinforcing feedback loop is created by which, if it is allowed to proceed uninhibited, the winners eventually take all, while the losers are eliminated.
如果比赛的获胜者得到系统性的奖励，从而有机会再次获胜，就会形成一个强化反馈回路。如果这种回路不受限制地发展下去，最终获胜者将独占鳌头，而失败者则会被淘汰。
THE WAY OUT
出路
Diversification, which allows those who are losing the competition to get out of that game and start another one; strict limitation on the fraction of the pie any one winner may win (antitrust laws); policies that level the playing field, removing some of the advantage of the strongest players or increasing the advantage of the weakest; policies that devise rewards for success that do not bias the next round of competition.
多元化经营，允许那些在竞争中失败的人退出当前的竞争，并开始另一场竞争；严格限制任何一个赢家可以赢得的蛋糕份额（反垄断法）；创造公平竞争环境的政策，消除强者的一些优势或增加弱者的优势；制定奖励成功的政策，但这些奖励不会影响下一轮竞争。

Shifting the Burden to the Intervenor— Addiction

将负担转移给干预者——成瘾

You get some sense of what an incredible downward spiral we’re in. Because more costs keep being shifted to the private sector, more private sector people stop insuring their employees. We are . . . now up to 100,000 Americans a month losing their health insurance.
你大概能感受到我们正陷入多么可怕的恶性循环。由于越来越多的成本转移到私营部门，越来越多的私营部门人士停止为员工购买医疗保险。现在，每月有多达10万美国人失去医疗保险。
An enormous percentage of them qualify for state Medicaid benefits. And since states can’t run a deficit, they all go out and either underfund education, or underfund children’s investment programs, or raise taxes, and that takes money away from other investments.
他们当中有相当一部分人符合州政府医疗补助计划的资格。由于各州不能出现财政赤字，所以他们要么削减教育经费，要么削减儿童投资项目经费，要么提高税收，而这又会减少其他投资的资金。
—Bill Clinton, International Herald Tribune , 1992 11
——比尔·克林顿，《国际先驱论坛报》，1992年
If you want to make a Somali angry, it is said, take away his khat. . . .
据说，如果你想惹索马里人生气，就拿走他的卡特叶……
Khat is the fresh tender leaves and twigs of the catha edulis plant.
卡特草是卡塔杜鹃植物的新鲜嫩叶和嫩枝。
. . . It is pharmacologically related to amphetamines. . . . Abdukadr Mahmoud Farah, 22, said he first started chewing khat when he was 15. . . . “The reason is not to think of this place. When I use it, I get happy. I can do everything. I do not get tired.”
……它在药理学上与安非他明类似。……22岁的阿卜杜卡德尔·马哈茂德·法拉赫说，他15岁就开始嚼卡特叶。……“嚼卡特叶是为了不去想这个地方。嚼完之后，我感觉很开心，精力充沛，什么都能做，而且不会觉得累。”
—Keith B. Richburg, International Herald Tribune , 1992 12
——基思·B·里奇伯格，《国际先驱论坛报》，1992年

Most people understand the addictive properties of alcohol, nicotine, caffeine, sugar, and heroin. Not everyone recognizes that addiction can appear in larger systems and in other guises—such as the dependence of industry on government subsidy, the reliance of farmers on fertilizers, the addiction of Western economies to cheap oil or weapons manufacturers to government contracts.

大多数人都了解酒精、尼古丁、咖啡因、糖和海洛因的成瘾性。但并非所有人都意识到，成瘾也会以其他形式出现在更大的系统中——例如，工业对政府补贴的依赖、农民对化肥的依赖、西方经济体对廉价石油的依赖，以及武器制造商对政府合同的依赖。

This trap is known by many names: addiction, dependence, shifting the burden to the intervenor. The structure includes a stock with in-flows and out-flows. The stock can be physical (a crop of corn) or meta -physical (a sense of well-being or self-worth). The stock is maintained by an actor adjusting a balancing feedback loop—either altering the in-flows or outflows. The actor has a goal and compares it with a perception of the actual state of the stock to determine what action to take.

这种陷阱有很多名称：成瘾、依赖、将负担转移给干预者。其结构包含一个有流入和流出的“存量”。存量可以是物质的（例如玉米收成），也可以是精神的（例如幸福感或自我价值感）。存量由行动者通过调整平衡反馈回路来维持——通过改变流入或流出来实现。行动者有一个目标，并将其与对存量实际状态的感知进行比较，以决定采取何种行动。

Say you are a young boy, living in a land of famine and war, and your goal is to boost your sense of well-being so you feel happy and energetic and There is a huge discrepancy between your desired and actual state, and there are very few options available to you for closing that gap. But one thing you can do is take drugs. The drugs do nothing to improve your real situation—in fact, they likely make it worse. But the drugs quickly alter your perception of your state, numbing your senses and making you feel tireless and brave.

假设你是一个生活在饥荒和战乱之地的男孩，你的目标是提升幸福感，让自己感到快乐和精力充沛。然而，你理想中的状态与现实之间存在着巨大的差距，而弥合这种差距的方法却寥寥无几。但你可以做的一件事就是服用毒品。毒品并不能改善你的真实处境——事实上，它们很可能会让情况变得更糟。但毒品会迅速改变你对自身状态的感知，麻痹你的感官，让你感到不知疲倦、勇敢无畏。

Similarly, if you are running an ineffective company, and if you can get the government to subsidize you, you can go on making money and continue to have a good profit, thereby remaining a respected member of society. Or perhaps you are a farmer trying to increase your corn crop on overworked land. You apply fertilizers and get a bumper crop without doing anything to improve the fertility of the soil.

同样，如果你经营一家效率低下的公司，但能获得政府补贴，你就能继续赚钱，保持良好的利润，从而继续受人尊敬。又或者，你是一位农民，试图在过度耕作的土地上提高玉米产量。你施肥后获得了丰收，却没有采取任何措施来改善土壤肥力。

The trouble is that the states created by interventions don’t last. The intoxication wears off. The subsidy is spent. The fertilizer is consumed or washed away.

问题在于，干预措施所创造的局面无法持久。兴奋感会消退，补贴会耗尽，肥料会被消耗或冲走。

Examples of dependence and burden-shifting systems abound:

依赖和负担转移系统的例子比比皆是：

• Care of the aged used to be carried on by families, not always easily. So along came Social Security, retirement communities, nursing homes. Now most families no longer have the space, the time, the skills, or the willingness to care for their elderly members.
过去，照顾老人主要由家庭承担，但这并非易事。因此，社会保障、退休社区和养老院应运而生。如今，大多数家庭已不再拥有足够的空间、时间、技能或意愿来照顾家中的老人。
• Long-distance shipping was carried by railroads and short distance commuting by subways and streetcars, until the government decided to help out by building highways.
• 长途运输依靠铁路，短途通勤依靠地铁和有轨电车，直到政府决定修建高速公路来提供帮助。
• Kids used to be able to do arithmetic in their heads or with paper and pencil, before the widespread use of calculators.
• 在计算器普及之前，孩子们通常可以用心算或者用纸笔进行算术运算。
• Populations built up a partial immunity to diseases such as smallpox, tuberculosis, and malaria, until vaccinations and drugs came along.
• 在疫苗和药物出现之前，人们逐渐对天花、肺结核和疟疾等疾病产生了一定的免疫力。
• Modern medicine in general has shifted the responsibility for health away from the practices and lifestyle of each individual and onto intervening doctors and medicines.
• 现代医学总体上已经将健康责任从个人的习惯和生活方式转移到了医生和药物的干预上。

Shifting a burden to an intervenor can be a good thing. It often is done purposefully, and the result can be an increased ability to keep the system in a desirable state. Surely the 100 percent protection from smallpox vaccines, if it lasts, is preferable to only partial protection from natural smallpox immunity. Some systems really need an intervenor!

将负担转移给干预者可能是一件好事。这种做法通常是有意为之，其结果可以增强系统维持理想状态的能力。当然，如果天花疫苗能提供持久的100%保护，那肯定比仅靠自然天花免疫提供的部分保护要好得多。有些系统确实需要干预！

But the intervention can become a system trap. A corrective feedback process within the system is doing a poor (or even so-so) job of maintaining the state of the system. A well-meaning and efficient intervenor watches the struggle and steps in to take some of the load. The intervenor quickly brings the system to the state everybody wants it to be in. Congratulations are in order, usually self-congratulations by the intervenor to the intervenor.

但这种干预可能会变成系统陷阱。系统内部的纠正性反馈机制在维持系统状态方面表现不佳（甚至差强人意）。一位善意且高效的干预者目睹了这种困境，并介入分担部分负担。干预者迅速将系统调整到人人期望的状态。这时，人们会互相祝贺，通常是干预者向自己表示祝贺。

Then the original problem reappears, since nothing has been done to solve it at its root cause. So the intervenor applies more of the “solution,” disguising the real state of the system again, and thereby failing to act on the problem. That makes it necessary to use still more “solution.”

然后，由于没有从根本上解决问题，最初的问题再次出现。于是，干预者又应用了更多的“解决方案”，再次掩盖了系统的真实状况，从而未能真正解决问题。这又导致需要使用更多的“解决方案”。

The trap is formed if the intervention, whether by active destruction or simple neglect, undermines the original capacity of the system to maintain itself. If that capability atrophies, then more of the intervention is needed to achieve the desired effect. That weakens the capability of the original system still more. The intervenor picks up the slack. And so forth.

如果干预——无论是主动破坏还是简单的忽视——削弱了系统原本的自我维持能力，陷阱就形成了。如果这种能力萎缩，就需要更多的干预才能达到预期效果。这又会进一步削弱原有系统的能力。干预者填补了这一空缺。如此循环往复。

Why does anyone enter the trap? First, the intervenor may not foresee that the initial urge to help out a bit can start a chain of events that leads to ever-increasing dependency, which ultimately will strain the capacity of the intervenor. The American health-care system is experiencing the strains of that sequence of events.

为什么有人会落入这个陷阱？首先，介入者可能没有预料到，最初想要伸出援手的冲动会引发一系列事件，导致依赖性不断加深，最终耗尽介入者的能力。美国的医疗保健系统正承受着这一系列事件带来的压力。

Second, the individual or community that is being helped may not think through the long term loss of control and the increased vulnerability that go along with the opportunity to shift a burden to an able and powerful intervenor.

其次，接受帮助的个人或社区可能没有考虑到，将负担转移给有能力且强大的干预者所带来的长期控制权丧失和脆弱性增加。

If the intervention is a drug, you become addicted. The more you are sucked into an addictive action, the more you are sucked into it again. One definition of addiction used in Alcoholics Anonymous is repeating the same stupid behavior over and over and over, and somehow expecting different results.

如果干预手段是药物，你就会上瘾。你越是沉迷于某种成瘾行为，就越容易再次沉迷其中。匿名戒酒会中对成瘾的一种定义是：一遍又一遍地重复同样的愚蠢行为，却期待不同的结果。

Addiction is finding a quick and dirty solution to the symptom of the problem, which prevents or distracts one from the harder and longer-term task of solving the real problem. Addictive policies are insidious, because they are so easy to sell, so simple to fall for.

成瘾是指寻找快速简便的方法来缓解问题的症状，但这会妨碍或分散人们对解决真正问题的注意力，使人无法完成更艰巨、更长期的任务。成瘾性保险产品之所以具有隐蔽性，是因为它们很容易推销，也很容易让人上当受骗。

Are insects threatening the crops? Rather than examine the farming the monocultures, the destruction of natural ecosystem controls that have led to the pest outbreak, just apply pesticides. That will make the bugs go away, and allow more monocultures, more destruction of ecosystems. That will bring back the bugs in greater outbursts, requiring more pesticides in the future.

虫害真的威胁到庄稼了吗？人们不去探究单一作物种植的弊端，以及导致虫害爆发的自然生态系统控制机制遭到破坏的原因，而是简单地喷洒杀虫剂。这样做或许能暂时消灭害虫，但也会让更多的单一作物种植成为可能，进一步破坏生态系统。而这又会导致害虫卷土重来，而且数量更大，未来需要使用更多的杀虫剂。

Is the price of oil going up? Rather than acknowledge the inevitable depletion of a nonrenewable resource and increase fuel efficiency or switch to other fuels, we can fix the price . (Both the Soviet Union and the United States did this as their first response to the oil price shocks of the 1970s.) That way we can pretend that nothing is happening and go on burning oil—making the depletion problem worse. When that policy breaks down, we can go to war for oil. Or find more oil. Like a drunk ransacking the house in hopes of unearthing just one more bottle, we can pollute the beaches and invade the last wilderness areas, searching for just one more big deposit of oil.

油价上涨了吗？与其承认不可再生资源的必然枯竭，提高燃油效率或改用其他燃料，我们不如人为地操纵油价。（苏联和美国在20世纪70年代应对油价冲击的第一反应就是如此。）这样一来，我们就可以假装一切如常，继续燃烧石油——从而加剧资源枯竭问题。一旦这项政策失效，我们就可以为了石油发动战争，或者去寻找更多的石油。就像醉汉翻遍房子只为找到最后一瓶酒一样，我们也可以污染海滩，侵占最后的荒野，只为寻找另一处大型油田。

Breaking an addiction is painful. It may be the physical pain of heroin withdrawal, or the economic pain of a price increase to reduce oil consumption, or the consequences of a pest invasion while natural predator populations are restoring themselves. Withdrawal means finally confronting the real (and usually much deteriorated) state of the system and taking the actions that the addiction allowed one to put off. Sometimes the withdrawal can be done gradually. Sometimes a nonaddictive policy can be put in place first to restore the degraded system with a minimum of turbulence (group support to restore the self-image of the addict, home insulation and high-mileage cars to reduce oil expense, polyculture and crop rotation to reduce crop vulnerability to pests). Sometimes there’s no way out but to go cold turkey and just bear the pain.

戒除毒瘾是痛苦的。这可能是海洛因戒断带来的身体疼痛，也可能是为减少石油消耗而导致的价格上涨带来的经济痛苦，或是害虫入侵导致天敌种群恢复过程中的种种后果。戒断意味着最终要直面系统真实的（通常是严重恶化的）状态，并采取那些因毒瘾而一直拖延的行动。有时，戒断可以循序渐进。有时，可以先实施一些非成瘾性政策，以尽可能减少系统动荡的方式恢复其功能（例如，通过团体支持来重塑成瘾者的自我形象，通过房屋隔热和使用高里程汽车来降低石油支出，通过多种作物混作和轮作来降低作物遭受病虫害侵袭的风险）。有时，别无他法，只能彻底戒断，默默承受痛苦。

It’s worth going through the withdrawal to get back to an unaddicted state, but it is far preferable to avoid addiction in the first place.

经历戒断反应才能恢复到无毒状态是值得的，但最好还是从一开始就避免上瘾。

The problem can be avoided up front by intervening in such a way as to strengthen the ability of the system to shoulder its own burdens . This option, helping the system to help itself, can be much cheaper and easier than taking over and running the system—something liberal politicians don’t seem to understand. The secret is to begin not with a heroic takeover, but with a series of questions.

这个问题可以通过预先干预来避免，从而增强系统自身承担责任的能力。这种帮助系统自助的方案，比接管和运营系统要便宜得多，也容易得多——这一点自由派政客似乎并不理解。关键在于，不要一开始就采取英雄式的接管行动，而是要从一系列问题入手。

• Why are the natural correction mechanisms failing?

• 为什么自然纠正机制会失效？

• How can obstacles to their success be removed?

如何消除阻碍他们成功的障碍？

• How can mechanisms for their success be made more effective?

如何才能使促进其成功的机制更加有效？

THE TRAP: SHIFTING THE BURDEN TO THE INTERVENOR
陷阱：将负担转移给干预者
Shifting the burden, dependence, and addiction arise when a solution to a systemic problem reduces (or disguises) the symptoms, but does nothing to solve the underlying problem. Whether it is a substance that dulls one’s perception or a policy that hides the underlying trouble, the drug of choice interferes with the actions that could solve the real problem.
当系统性问题的解决方案仅仅减轻（或掩盖）了症状，却未能解决根本问题时，就会出现负担转移、依赖和成瘾现象。无论是麻痹感知能力的物质，还是掩盖潜在问题的政策，人们选择的“药物”都会阻碍那些本可以解决真正问题的行动。
If the intervention designed to correct the problem causes the self-maintaining capacity of the original system to atrophy or erode, then a destructive reinforcing feedback loop is set in motion. The system deteriorates; more and more of the solution is then required. The system will become more and more dependent on the intervention and less and less able to maintain its own desired state.
如果旨在纠正问题的干预措施导致原有系统的自我维持能力萎缩或削弱，就会启动一个破坏性的正反馈回路。系统恶化，需要越来越多的解决方案。系统将越来越依赖干预措施，越来越难以维持自身所需的理想状态。
THE WAY OUT
出路
Again, the best way out of this trap is to avoid getting in. Beware of symptom-relieving or signal-denying policies or practices that don’t really address the problem. Take the focus off short-term relief and put it on long term restructuring.
再次强调，摆脱这种陷阱的最佳方法就是避免落入其中。要警惕那些只能缓解症状或掩盖问题的政策或做法，它们并不能真正解决问题。不要只关注短期缓解，而应该着眼于长期重组。

If you are the intervenor, work in such a way as to restore or enhance the system’s own ability to solve its problems, then remove yourself.

如果你是干预者，那就努力恢复或增强系统自身解决问题的能力，然后退出。

If you are the one with an unsupportable dependency, build your system’s own capabilities back up before removing the intervention. Do it right away. The longer you wait, the harder the withdrawal process will be.

如果你已经对某种东西产生了无法承受的依赖，那么在移除这种依赖之前，务必先重建自身系统的能力。而且要立即行动。拖得越久，戒断过程就越困难。

Rule Beating

违反规则

CALVIN: OK, Hobbes, I’ve got a plan.
卡尔文：好的，霍布斯，我有个计划。
HOBBES: Yeah?
霍布斯：嗯？
CALVIN: If I do ten spontaneous acts of good will a day from now until Christmas, Santa will have to be lenient in judging the rest of this last year. I can claim I’ve turned a new leaf.
卡尔文：如果我从现在到圣诞节每天都自发地做十件善事，圣诞老人就不得不对我今年剩下的时间宽容一些。我可以宣称自己改过自新了。
HOBBES: Well, here’s your chance. Susie’s coming this way.
霍布斯：好，机会来了。苏西正朝这边走来。
CALVIN: Maybe I’ll start tomorrow and do 20 a day.
卡尔文：也许我明天就开始，一天做20个。
— International Herald Tribune , 1992 13
—国际先驱论坛报，1992年

Wherever there are rules, there is likely to be rule beating. Rule beating means evasive action to get around the intent of a system’s rules—abiding by the letter, but not the spirit, of the law. Rule beating becomes a problem only when it leads a system into large distortions, unnatural behaviors that would make no sense at all in the absence of the rules. If it gets out of hand, rule beating can cause systems to produce very damaging behavior indeed.

凡是有规则的地方，就可能出现规避规则的行为。规避规则指的是规避系统规则的意图——遵守法律的字面意思，却不遵循法律的精神。只有当规避规则导致系统出现巨大的扭曲，产生在没有规则的情况下根本无法理解的反常行为时，它才会成为问题。如果情况失控，规避规则会导致系统产生极其有害的行为。

Rule beating that distorts nature, the economy, organizations, and the human spirit can be destructive. Here are some examples, some serious, some less so, of rule beating:

滥用规则扭曲自然、经济、组织和人性，会造成破坏。以下是一些滥用规则的例子，有些性质严重，有些则较轻：

• Departments of governments, universities, and corporations often engage in pointless spending at the end of the fiscal year just to get rid of money—because if they don’t spend their budget this year, they will be allocated less next year.
• 政府部门、大学和公司经常在财政年度末进行毫无意义的支出，只是为了把钱花掉——因为如果他们今年不花完预算，明年分配给他们的资金就会减少。
• In the 1970s, the state of Vermont adopted a land-use law called Act 250 that requires a complex approval process for subdivisions that create lots of ten acres or less. Now Vermont has an extraordinary number of lots just a little over ten acres.
• 上世纪70年代，佛蒙特州通过了一项名为《第250号法案》的土地使用法，该法案规定，面积小于等于10英亩的地块分割需要经过复杂的审批程序。如今，佛蒙特州拥有数量惊人的面积略大于10英亩的地块。
• To reduce grain imports and assist local grain farmers, European countries imposed import restrictions on feed grains in the 1960s. No one thought, while the restrictions were being drafted, about the starchy root called cassava, which also happens to be a good animal feed. Cassava was not included in the restrictions. So corn imports from North America were replaced by cassava imports from Asia. 14
为了减少粮食进口并扶持当地粮食种植户，欧洲各国在20世纪60年代对饲料谷物实施了进口限制。然而，在制定这些限制措施时，没有人想到木薯这种富含淀粉的根茎作物，它恰好也是一种优质的动物饲料。木薯并未被纳入限制范围。因此，原本从北美进口的玉米被从亚洲进口的木薯所取代。
• The U.S. Endangered Species Act restricts development wherever an endangered species has its habitat. Some landowners, on discovering that their property harbors an endangered species, purposely hunt or poison it, so the land can be developed.
美国《濒危物种法》限制在濒危物种栖息地进行开发。一些土地所有者在发现自己的土地上栖息着濒危物种后，会故意猎杀或毒杀这些物种，以便开发土地。

Notice that rule beating produces the appearance of rules being followed. Drivers obey the speed limits, when they’re in the vicinity of a police car. Feed grains are no longer imported into Europe. Development does not proceed where an endangered species is documented as present. The “letter of the law” is met, the spirit of the law is not. That is a warning about needing to design the law with the whole system, including its self-organizing evasive possibilities, in mind.

请注意，规避规则会造成遵守规则的假象。司机在警车附近时会遵守限速规定。饲料谷物不再进口到欧洲。濒危物种被发现存在于某地时，开发项目就不会进行。法律的“字面”得到了遵守，但法律的精神却被忽视了。这警示我们，在制定法律时，必须考虑到整个系统，包括其自我组织规避的可能性。

Rule beating is usually a response of the lower levels in a hierarchy to overrigid, deleterious, unworkable, or ill-defined rules from above. There are two generic responses to rule beating. One is to try to stamp out the self-organizing response by strengthening the rules or their enforcement—usually giving rise to still greater system distortion. That’s the way further into the trap.

规避规则通常是层级结构中较低层级对上层过于僵化、有害、不切实际或定义不清的规则的一种回应。对于规避规则的行为，通常有两种应对方式。一种是试图通过加强规则或强化规则执行来扼杀这种自组织行为——但这通常会导致系统进一步扭曲。这样做只会让自己越陷越深。

The way out of the trap, the opportunity, is to understand rule beating as useful feedback, and to revise, improve, rescind, or better explain the rules. Designing rules better means foreseeing as far as possible the effects of the rules on the subsystems, including any rule beating they might engage in, and structuring the rules to turn the self-organizing capabilities of the system in a positive direction.

摆脱困境的出路和机遇在于将违反规则的行为理解为有益的反馈，并据此修订、改进、撤销或更好地解释规则。更好地设计规则意味着尽可能预见规则对子系统的影响，包括子系统可能出现的任何违反规则的行为，并构建规则以引导系统的自组织能力朝着积极的方向发展。

THE TRAP: RULE BEATING
陷阱：钻规则空子
Rules to govern a system can lead to rule beating—perverse behavior that gives the appearance of obeying the rules or achieving the goals, but that actually distorts the system.
管理系统的规则可能会导致违反规则——这种反常行为表面上是在遵守规则或实现目标，但实际上却扭曲了系统。
THE WAY OUT
出路
Design, or redesign, rules to release creativity not in the direction of beating the rules, but in the direction of achieving the purpose of the rules.
设计或重新设计规则，是为了释放创造力，不是为了让创造力去违反规则，而是为了让创造力去实现规则的目的。

Seeking the Wrong Goal

追求错误的目标

The government formally acknowledged Friday what private economists have been saying for months: Japan will not come close to hitting the 3.5 percent growth target government planners set a year ago. . . .
日本政府周五正式承认了私人经济学家几个月来一直预言的观点：日本经济将远未达到政府一年前设定的3.5%的增长目标。
GNP grew in 1991 by 3.5 percent and in 1990 by 5.5 percent. Since the beginning of this fiscal year . . . the economy has been stagnant or contracting. . . .
1991年国民生产总值增长了3.5%，1990年增长了5.5%。自本财年开始以来……经济一直处于停滞或萎缩状态……
Now that the forecast . . . has been lowered sharply, pressure from politicians and business is likely to grow on the Finance Ministry to take stimulative measures.
既然预测已被大幅下调，政界和商界对财政部的压力可能会越来越大，要求其采取刺激措施。
— International Herald Tribune , 1992 15
—国际先驱论坛报，1992年

Back in Chapter One, I said that one of the most powerful ways to influence the behavior of a system is through its purpose or goal. That’s because the goal is the direction-setter of the system, the definer of discrepancies that require action, the indicator of compliance, failure, or success toward which balancing feedback loops work. If the goal is defined badly, if it doesn’t measure what it’s supposed to measure, if it doesn’t reflect the real welfare of the system, then the system can’t possibly produce a desirable result. Systems, like the three wishes in the traditional fairy tale, have a terrible tendency to produce exactly and only what you ask them to produce. Be careful what you ask them to produce.

在第一章中，我说过，影响系统行为最有效的方法之一就是通过其目标或目的。这是因为目标是系统的方向指引者，是需要采取行动的偏差的界定者，也是衡量系统是否达标、失败或成功的指标，而平衡反馈回路正是朝着这个方向运作的。如果目标定义不当，如果它没有衡量它应该衡量的东西，如果它没有反映系统的真实状况，那么系统就不可能产生理想的结果。系统就像传统童话故事里的三个愿望一样，有一个可怕的倾向：它们只会产生你要求它们产生的东西。所以，务必谨慎地要求它们产生什么。

If the desired system state is national security, and that is defined as the amount of money spent on the military, the system will produce military spending. It may or may not produce national security. In fact, security may be undermined if the spending drains investment from other parts of the economy, and if the spending goes for exorbitant, unnecessary, or unworkable weapons.

如果期望的系统状态是国家安全，而国家安全又被定义为军费开支，那么该系统必然会产生军费开支。但它是否真的能带来国家安全，则未必如此。事实上，如果军费开支吸走了经济其他领域的投资，或者用于购买过高、不必要或不实用的武器，那么国家安全反而可能受到损害。

If the desired system state is good education, measuring that goal by the amount of money spent per student will ensure money spent per student. If the quality of education is measured by performance on standardized tests, the system will produce performance on standardized tests. Whether either of these measures is correlated with good education is at least worth thinking about.

如果理想的系统状态是优质教育，那么以生均教育投入来衡量这一目标，就能确保生均教育投入到位。如果以标准化考试成绩来衡量教育质量，那么系统最终只会产出标准化考试成绩优异的教育。这两种衡量标准是否与优质教育相关，至少值得我们深思。

In the early days of family planning in India, program goals were defined in terms of the number of IUDs implanted. So doctors, in their eagerness to meet their targets, put loops into women without patient approval.

在印度计划生育的早期阶段，项目目标以宫内节育器植入数量来衡量。因此，医生们为了完成指标，未经患者同意就将节育器植入女性体内。

These examples confuse effort with result, one of the most common mistakes in designing systems around the wrong goal. Maybe the worst mistake of this kind has been the adoption of the GNP as the measure of national economic success. The GNP is the gross national product, the money value of the final goods and services produced by the economy. As a measure of human welfare, it has been criticized almost from the moment it was invented:

这些例子混淆了努力和结果，这是围绕错误目标设计系统时最常见的错误之一。也许这类错误中最严重的莫过于采用国民生产总值（GNP）作为衡量国家经济成功的标准。国民生产总值是指一个经济体生产的最终商品和服务的货币价值。作为衡量人类福祉的指标，它几乎从诞生之日起就饱受诟病：

The gross national product does not allow for the health of our children, the quality of their education or the joy of their play. It does not include the beauty of our poetry or the strength of our marriages, the intelligence of our public debate or the integrity of our public officials. It measures neither our wit nor our courage, neither our wisdom nor our learning, neither our compassion nor our devotion to our country, it measures everything in short, except that which makes life worthwhile. 16
国民生产总值无法体现我们孩子的健康、教育质量或玩耍的乐趣。它不包含我们诗歌的优美、婚姻的稳固、公共辩论的智慧或公职人员的正直。它既不能衡量我们的机智，也不能衡量我们的勇气；既不能衡量我们的智慧，也不能衡量我们的学识；既不能衡量我们的同情心，也不能衡量我们对国家的忠诚。简而言之，它衡量一切，唯独忽略了那些使生活更有意义的东西。
We have a system of national accounting that bears no resemblance to the national economy whatsoever, for it is not the record of our life at home but the fever chart of our consumption. 17
我们的国民经济核算体系与国民经济毫无关联，因为它记录的不是我们的家庭生活，而是我们的消费曲线图。

The GNP lumps together goods and bads. (If there are more car accidents and medical bills and repair bills, the GNP goes up.) It counts only marketed goods and services. (If all parents hired people to bring up their children, the GNP would go up.) It does not reflect distributional equity. (An expensive second home for a rich family makes the GNP go up more than an inexpensive basic home for a poor family.) It measures effort rather than achievement, gross production and consumption rather than efficiency. New light bulbs that give the same light with one-eighth the electricity and that last ten times as long make the GNP go down.

国民生产总值（GNP）将商品和服务混为一谈。（如果车祸、医疗费用和维修费用增加，GNP就会上升。）它只统计市场化的商品和服务。（如果所有父母都雇人抚养孩子，GNP也会上升。）它没有反映分配公平。（富裕家庭购买昂贵的第二套住房比贫困家庭购买廉价的基本住房更能提高GNP。）它衡量的是努力而非成就，是总产出和总消费而非效率。用八分之一的电量就能达到相同亮度、使用寿命却是旧灯泡十倍的新型灯泡，反而会降低GNP。

GNP is a measure of throughput —flows of stuff made and purchased in a year—rather than capital stocks, the houses and cars and computers and stereos that are the source of real wealth and real pleasure. It could be argued that the best society would be one in which capital stocks can be and used with the lowest possible throughput, rather than the highest.

国民生产总值衡量的是吞吐量——即一年内生产和购买的商品流量——而不是资本存量，也就是那些真正带来财富和真正快乐的房屋、汽车、电脑和音响等。可以说，最好的社会应该是资本存量能够以尽可能低的吞吐量而非最高的吞吐量被利用的社会。

Although there is every reason to want a thriving economy, there is no particular reason to want the GNP to go up. But governments around the world respond to a signal of faltering GNP by taking numerous actions to keep it growing. Many of those actions are simply wasteful, stimulating inefficient production of things no one particularly wants. Some of them, such as overharvesting forests in order to stimulate the economy in the short term, threaten the long term good of the economy or the society or the environment.

尽管我们完全有理由希望经济繁荣发展，但并没有特别的理由希望国民生产总值（GNP）持续增长。然而，世界各国政府一旦发现国民生产总值增长放缓的信号，便会采取各种措施来维持其增长。其中许多措施纯属浪费，刺激了低效的生产，而这些生产的产品并非人们真正需要的。有些措施，例如为了短期刺激经济而过度砍伐森林，则会威胁到经济、社会或环境的长期利益。

If you define the goal of a society as GNP, that society will do its best to produce GNP. It will not produce welfare, equity, justice, or efficiency unless you define a goal and regularly measure and report the state of welfare, equity, justice, or efficiency. The world would be a different place if instead of competing to have the highest per capita GNP, nations competed to have the highest per capita stocks of wealth with the lowest throughput, or the lowest infant mortality, or the greatest political freedom, or the cleanest environment, or the smallest gap between the rich and the poor.

如果将社会的目标定义为国民生产总值（GNP），那么这个社会就会竭尽全力去创造GNP。除非设定目标并定期衡量和报告福利、公平、正义或效率的状况，否则它不会创造这些目标。如果各国不再竞相追求最高的人均GNP，而是竞相追求最高的人均财富存量（同时保持最低的人口吞吐量）、最低的婴儿死亡率、最大的政治自由度、最清洁的环境或最小的贫富差距，那么世界将会截然不同。

Seeking the wrong goal, satisfying the wrong indicator, is a system characteristic almost opposite from rule beating. In rule beating, the system is out to evade an unpopular or badly designed rule, while giving the appearance of obeying it. In seeking the wrong goal, the system obediently follows the rule and produces its specified result—which is not necessarily what anyone actually wants. You have the problem of wrong goals when you find something stupid happening “because it’s the rule.” You have the problem of rule beating when you find something stupid happening because it’s the way around the rule. Both of these system perversions can be going on at the same time with regard to the same rule.

追求错误的目标，满足错误的指标，是系统的一种特性，几乎与规避规则截然相反。规避规则是指系统试图规避不受欢迎或设计糟糕的规则，同时表面上却遵守规则。而追求错误的目标则是指系统顺从地遵循规则并产生其预设的结果——但这未必是任何人真正想要的。当你发现某些愚蠢的事情“因为这是规则”发生时，你遇到的就是目标错误的问题。当你发现某些愚蠢的事情“因为这是规避规则的方法”发生时，你遇到的就是规避规则的问题。这两种系统偏差可能同时发生，并且都与同一条规则相关。

THE TRAP: SEEKING THE WRONG GOAL
陷阱：追求错误的目标
System behavior is particularly sensitive to the goals of feedback loops. If the goals—the indicators of satisfaction of the rules—are defined inaccurately or incompletely, the system may obediently work to produce a result that is not really intended or wanted.
系统行为对反馈回路的目标尤为敏感。如果目标（即规则满足程度的指标）定义不准确或不完整，系统可能会盲目地产生并非真正预期或期望的结果。
THE WAY OUT
出路
Specify indicators and goals that reflect the real welfare of the system. Be especially careful not to confuse effort with result or you will end up with a system that is producing effort, not result.
明确能够反映系统实际效能的指标和目标。尤其要注意不要将努力与结果混淆，否则最终得到的系统只会产生努力，而不会产生结果。

INTERLUDE • The Goal of Sailboat Design

插曲 • 帆船设计的目标

Once upon a time, people raced sailboats not for millions of dollars or for national glory, but just for the fun of it.

从前，人们参加帆船比赛不是为了赢得数百万美元或国家荣耀，而只是为了享受其中的乐趣。

They raced the boats they already had for normal purposes, boats that were designed for fishing, or transporting goods, or sailing around on weekends.

他们驾驶着原本用于正常用途的船只进行比赛，这些船只原本是为捕鱼、运输货物或周末出海航行而设计的。

It quickly was observed that races are more interesting if the competitors are roughly equal in speed and maneuverability. So rules evolved, that defined various classes of boat by length and sail area and other parameters, and that restricted races to competitors of the same class.

人们很快发现，如果参赛船只的速度和操控性能大致相当，比赛会更有趣。因此，规则逐渐形成，根据船长、帆面积和其他参数将船只划分为不同的级别，并将比赛限制在同一级别的船只之间进行。

Soon boats were being designed not for normal sailing, but for winning races within the categories defined by the rules. They squeezed the last possible burst of speed out of a square inch of sail, or the lightest possible load out of a standard-sized rudder. These boats were strange-looking and strange-handling, not at all the sort of boat you would want to take out fishing or for a Sunday sail. As the races became more serious, the rules became stricter and the boat designs more bizarre.

很快，人们设计的船只不再是为了日常航行，而是为了在规则规定的类别中赢得比赛。他们竭尽所能，从每一平方英寸的帆中榨取最后一丝速度，或者从标准尺寸的舵中尽可能减轻负荷。这些船只外形奇特，操控起来也十分怪异，绝非那种适合出海钓鱼或休闲航行的船只。随着比赛的日益激烈，规则也愈加严格，船只的设计也愈发奇特。

Now racing sailboats are extremely fast, highly responsive, and nearly unseaworthy. They need athletic and expert crews to manage them. No one would think of using an America’s Cup yacht for any purpose other than racing within the rules. The boats are so optimized around the present rules that they have lost all resilience. Any change in the rules would render them useless.

如今的赛艇速度极快、操控灵敏，但几乎不适于远航。它们需要体能充沛且经验丰富的船员来驾驭。没有人会想到将美洲杯帆船用于规则之外的任何用途。这些帆船已经完全围绕现有规则进行了优化，以至于失去了所有适应性。任何规则的改变都会使它们彻底失效。

#↩

PART THREE

第三部分

Creating Change—in Systems and in Our Philosophy

创造变革——在系统和理念层面

#↩

— SIX —

- 六 -

Leverage Points—
杠杆点——


Places to Intervene in a System
系统中的干预点
_____________
IBM . . . announced 25,000 new job cuts and a large reduction in spending on research. . . . Spending on development research is to be lowered by $1 billion next year. . . . Chairman John K. Akers . . . said IBM was still a world and industry leader in research but felt it could do better by “shifting to areas for growth,” meaning services, which need less capital but also return less profit in the long run.
IBM宣布裁员2.5万人，并大幅削减研发支出。明年，IBM的研发支出将减少10亿美元。董事长约翰·K·阿克斯表示，IBM在研发领域仍然是世界和行业的领导者，但他认为公司可以通过“转向增长领域”做得更好，这些领域指的是服务业，虽然服务业所需的资本较少，但从长远来看，其利润回报也较低。
—Lawrence Malkin, International Herald Tribune , 1992 1
——劳伦斯·马尔金，《国际先驱论坛报》，1992年

So, how do we change the structure of systems to produce more of what we want and less of that which is undesirable? After years of working with corporations on their systems problems, MIT’s Jay Forrester likes to say that the average manager can define the current problem very cogently, identify the system structure that leads to the problem, and guess with great accuracy where to look for leverage points—places in the system where a small change could lead to a large shift in behavior.

那么，我们该如何改变系统结构，从而生产出更多我们想要的东西，减少那些不想要的东西呢？麻省理工学院的杰伊·福雷斯特多年来一直与企业合作解决系统问题，他喜欢说，普通管理者都能非常清晰地定义当前问题，识别出导致问题的系统结构，并且能够非常准确地推测出哪里存在杠杆点——系统中那些只需做出微小改变就能引发行为巨大转变的地方。

This idea of leverage points is not unique to systems analysis—it’s embedded in legend: the silver bullet; the trimtab; the miracle cure; the secret passage; the magic password; the single hero who turns the tide of history; the nearly effortless way to cut through or leap over huge obstacles. We not only want to believe that there are leverage points, we want to know where they are and how to get our hands on them. Leverage points are points of power.

这种杠杆点的概念并非系统分析所独有——它早已融入各种传说：灵丹妙药；微调装置；神奇疗法；秘密通道；魔法密码；扭转历史的英雄；以及几乎毫不费力就能突破或跨越巨大障碍的方法。我们不仅想要相信杠杆点的存在，还想知道它们在哪里，以及如何才能抓住它们。杠杆点就是力量的源泉。

But Forrester goes on to point out that although people deeply involved in a system often know intuitively where to find leverage points, more often than not they push the change in the wrong direction .

但 Forrester 进一步指出，虽然深入参与系统的人通常凭直觉就知道在哪里可以找到杠杆点，但他们往往会把变革推向错误的方向。

The classic example of that backward intuition was my own introduction to systems analysis, the World model. Asked by the Club of Rome—an international group of businessmen, statesmen, and scientists—to show how major global problems of poverty and hunger, environmental destruction, resource depletion, urban deterioration, and unemployment are related and how they might be solved, Forrester made a computer model and came out with a clear leverage point: growth. 2 Not only population growth, but economic growth. Growth has costs as well as benefits, and we typically don’t count the costs—among which are poverty and hunger, environmental destruction, and so on—the whole list of problems we are trying to solve with growth! What is needed is much slower growth, very different kinds of growth, and in some cases no growth or negative growth.

这种本末倒置的直觉的经典例子，就是我初次接触系统分析——世界模型。罗马俱乐部（一个由商界人士、政治家和科学家组成的国际组织）邀请福雷斯特（Forrester）展示贫困和饥饿、环境破坏、资源枯竭、城市衰败和失业等重大全球性问题之间的关联，以及如何解决这些问题。福雷斯特建立了一个计算机模型，并提出了一个清晰的切入点：增长。 2 不仅是人口增长，还有经济增长。增长既有成本也有收益，而我们通常不会把成本——包括贫困和饥饿、环境破坏等等——计算在内，而我们试图用增长来解决的问题远不止这些！我们需要的是更缓慢的增长，截然不同的增长方式，在某些情况下，甚至需要零增长或负增长。

The world’s leaders are correctly fixated on economic growth as the answer to virtually all problems, but they’re pushing with all their might in the wrong direction .

世界各国领导人正确地将经济增长视为解决几乎所有问题的答案，但他们却竭尽全力朝着错误的方向努力。

Another of Forrester’s classics was his study of urban dynamics, published in 1969, which demonstrated that subsidized low-income housing is a leverage point. 3 World Bank, The less of it there is, the better off the city is—even the low-income folks in the city. This model came out at a time when national policy dictated massive low-income housing projects, and Forrester was derided. Since then, many of those projects have been torn down in city after city.

福雷斯特的另一部经典著作是他于1969年发表的城市动力学研究，该研究论证了补贴性低收入住房是一个杠杆点。世界银行指出，这类住房越少，城市就越富裕——即使是城市中的低收入人群也能从中受益。这一模型问世之时，正值国家政策大力推行大规模低收入住房项目，福雷斯特也因此饱受诟病。此后，许多此类项目在各个城市被拆除。

Counterintuitive —that’s Forrester’s word to describe complex systems. Leverage points frequently are not intuitive. Or if they are, we too often use them backward, systematically worsening whatever problems we are trying to solve.

反直觉——这是 Forrester 用来形容复杂系统的词语。杠杆点往往并非显而易见。即便显而易见，我们也常常本末倒置，反而系统性地加剧了我们试图解决的问题。

I have come up with no quick or easy formulas for finding leverage points in complex and dynamic systems. Give me a few months or years and I’ll figure it out. And I know from bitter experience that, because they are so counterintuitive, when I do discover a system’s leverage points, hardly anybody will believe me. Very frustrating—especially for those of us who yearn not just to understand complex systems, but to make the world work better.

我还没找到在复杂动态系统中寻找杠杆点的快捷简便方法。给我几个月甚至几年时间，我或许能找到。而且我从惨痛的经验中得知，由于杠杆点往往违反直觉，即使我发现了系统的杠杆点，也几乎没人会相信。这非常令人沮丧——尤其是对我们这些渴望不仅理解复杂系统，而且希望让世界运转得更好的人来说。

It was in just such a moment of frustration that I proposed a list of places to intervene in a system during a meeting on the implications of global trade regimes. I offer this list to you with much humility and wanting to leave room for its evolution. What bubbled up in me that day was distilled from decades of rigorous analysis of many different kinds of systems done by many smart people. But complex systems are, well, complex. It’s dangerous to generalize about them. What you read here is still a work in progress; it’s not a recipe for finding leverage points. Rather, it’s an invitation to think more broadly about system change.

正是在这种沮丧的时刻，我在一次关于全球贸易体制影响的会议上提出了一份系统干预点的清单。我怀着谦逊之心将这份清单呈献给大家，并希望它能不断完善。那天涌现的灵感源于数十年来众多杰出人士对各种不同类型系统的严谨分析。然而，复杂系统本身就十分复杂，对其进行概括性描述是危险的。您在这里读到的仍是一个不断完善的过程；它并非寻找有效干预点的万能指南，而是邀请您更广泛地思考系统变革。

As systems become complex, their behavior can become surprising. Think about your checking account. You write checks and make deposits. A little interest keeps flowing in (if you have a large enough balance) and bank fees flow out even if you have no money in the account, thereby creating an accumulation of debt. Now attach your account to a thousand others and let the bank create loans as a function of your combined and fluctuating deposits, link a thousand of those banks into a federal reserve system—and you begin to see how simple stocks and flows, plumbed together, create systems way too complicated and dynamically complex to figure out easily.

随着系统变得复杂，其行为也会变得出人意料。想想你的支票账户。你开支票、存款。即使账户余额不足，利息也会持续流入，而银行手续费也会不断流出，从而造成债务累积。现在，将你的账户与上千个其他账户关联起来，让银行根据你账户总额的波动情况发放贷款，再将这上千家银行连接到一个联邦储备系统——你就会明白，简单的存量和流量，一旦组合在一起，就会形成极其复杂且动态变化难以捉摸的系统。

That’s why leverage points are often not intuitive. And that’s enough systems theory to proceed to the list.

这就是为什么杠杆点往往不直观的原因。系统理论就讲到这里，我们可以继续看列表了。

12. Numbers—Constants and parameters such as subsidies, taxes, standards

12. 数字——诸如补贴、税收、标准等常量和参数

Think about the basic stock-and-flow bathtub from Chapter One. The size of the flows is a matter of numbers and how quickly those numbers can be changed. Maybe the faucet turns hard, so it takes a while to get the water flowing or to turn it off. Maybe the drain is blocked and can allow only a small flow, no matter how open it is. Maybe the faucet can deliver with the force of a fire hose. Some of these kinds of parameters are physically locked in and unchangeable, but many can be varied and so are popular intervention points.

想想第一章中提到的基本水量和流量的浴缸模型。流量的大小取决于数值以及这些数值变化的速度。也许水龙头很难拧开，所以需要一段时间才能出水或关掉水。也许排水管堵塞了，无论开多大，都只能排出少量水。也许水龙头出水量很大，像消防水管一样。有些参数是物理上固定的，无法改变，但很多参数是可以调整的，因此也是常用的干预点。

Consider the national debt. It may seem like a strange stock; it is a money hole. The rate at which the hole deepens is called the annual deficit. Income from taxes shrinks the hole, government expenditures expand it. Congress and the president spend most of their time arguing about the many, many parameters that increase (spending) and decrease (taxing) the size or depth of the hole. Since those flows are connected to us, the voters, these are politically charged parameters. But, despite all the fireworks, and no matter which party is in charge, the money hole has been deepening for years now, just at different rates.

想想国债。它看起来或许像个奇怪的股票，但实际上却是一个无底洞。这个无底洞不断加深的速度被称为年度赤字。税收收入可以缩小这个无底洞，而政府支出则会扩大它。国会和总统的大部分时间都花在争论那些影响无底洞大小或深度的诸多因素上，这些因素包括增加（支出）和减少（税收）。由于这些资金流动与我们选民息息相关，因此这些因素都带有浓厚的政治色彩。但是，尽管政治斗争激烈，无论哪个党派执政，这个无底洞多年来一直在加深，只是加深的速度有所不同。

To adjust the dirtiness of the air we breathe, the government sets parameters called ambient-air-quality standards. To ensure some standing stock of forest (or some flow of money to logging companies), it sets allowed annual cuts. Corporations adjust parameters such as wage rates and product prices, with an eye on the level in their profit bathtub—the bottom line.

为了调节我们呼吸的空气质量，政府制定了环境空气质量标准。为了确保森林的存量（或保证伐木公司的资金流动），政府设定了年度采伐量。企业则会根据利润水平——也就是最终的盈利情况——来调整工资水平和产品价格等参数。

The amount of land we set aside for conservation each year. The minimum wage. How much we spend on AIDS research or Stealth bombers. The service charge the bank extracts from your account. All of these are parameters, adjustments to faucets. So, by the way, is firing people and getting new ones, including politicians. Putting different hands on the faucets may change the rate at which the faucets turn, but if they’re the same old faucets, plumbed into the same old system, turned according to the same old information and goals and rules, the system behavior isn’t going to change much. Electing Bill Clinton was definitely different from electing the elder George Bush, but not all that different, given that every president is plugged into the same political system. (Changing the way money flows in that system would make much more of a difference—but I’m getting ahead of myself on this list.)

我们每年划拨的保护区面积。最低工资。我们在艾滋病研究或隐形轰炸机上的花费。银行从你账户中扣除的服务费。所有这些都是参数，是水龙头的调节装置。顺便说一句，解雇和任命新人，包括政客，也是如此。换个人来操作水龙头，可能会改变水龙头转动的速度，但如果水龙头还是老样子，连接着老系统，按照老信息、目标和规则运转，那么系统的运行方式不会有太大改变。选举比尔·克林顿和选举老布什当然不同，但考虑到每位总统都身处同一个政治体系，两者之间的差别并不大。（改变这个体系中的资金流动方式会产生更大的影响——但我在列举这些的时候有点跑题了。）

Numbers, the sizes of flows, are dead last on my list of powerful interventions. Diddling with the details, arranging the deck chairs on the Titanic. Probably 90—no 95, no 99 percent—of our attention goes to parameters, but there’s not a lot of leverage in them.

数字，也就是流量的大小，在我看来是最不重要的干预手段。纠结于细节，就像在泰坦尼克号上摆放甲板椅一样徒劳。我们可能90%——不，95%，甚至99%——的注意力都集中在参数上，但它们本身并不能带来多少实际的改变。

It’s not that parameters aren’t important—they can be, especially in the short term and to the individual who’s standing directly in the flow. People care deeply about such variables as taxes and the minimum wage, and so fight fierce battles over them. But changing these variables rarely changes the behavior of the national economy system . If the system is chronically stagnant, parameter changes rarely kick-start it. If it’s wildly variable, they usually don’t stabilize it. If it’s growing out of control, they don’t slow it down.

并非参数不重要——它们确实重要，尤其是在短期内，对于身处经济运行漩涡中的个人而言更是如此。人们非常关心税收和最低工资等变量，并为此展开激烈的争论。但改变这些变量很少能改变国民经济体系的运行规律。如果经济体系长期停滞不前，调整参数很少能使其恢复活力。如果经济体系波动剧烈，调整参数通常无法使其稳定下来。如果经济体系失控增长，调整参数也无法减缓其发展速度。

Whatever cap we put on campaign contributions, it doesn’t clean up politics. The Fed’s fiddling with the interest rate hasn’t made business cycles go away. (We always forget that during upturns, and are shocked, shocked by the downturns.) After decades of the strictest air pollution standards in the world, Los Angeles air is less dirty, but it isn’t clean. Spending more on police doesn’t make crime go away.

无论我们对竞选捐款设定多少上限，都无法净化政治。美联储调整利率并没有消除经济周期。（我们总是在经济上行时忘记这一点，并在经济下行时感到震惊。）经过几十年世界上最严格的空气污染标准，洛杉矶的空气污染有所减轻，但仍然不够清洁。增加警力投入也无法消除犯罪。

Since I’m about to get into some examples where parameters are leverage points, let me stick in a big caveat here. Parameters become leverage points when they go into ranges that kick off one of the items higher on this list. Interest rates, for example, or birth rates, control the gains around reinforcing feedback loops. System goals are parameters that can make big differences.

因为我接下来要举一些参数作为杠杆点的例子，所以这里我要先强调一点。当参数进入能够触发列表中更高层级某个因素的区间时，它们就变成了杠杆点。例如，利率或出生率控制着强化反馈回路的收益。系统目标是能够产生重大影响的参数。

These kinds of critical numbers are not nearly as common as people seem to think they are. Most systems have evolved or are designed to stay far out of range of critical parameters. Mostly, the numbers are not worth the sweat put into them.

这类临界值远没有人们想象的那么常见。大多数系统经过演化或设计，都旨在使自身参数远低于临界值。通常情况下，为了达到这些临界值而付出的努力并不值得。

Here’s a story a friend sent me over the Internet to makes that point:

以下是我朋友在网上发给我的一个故事，正好说明了这一点：

When I became a landlord, I spent a lot of time and energy trying to figure out what would be a “fair” rent to charge.
当我成为房东后，我花了很多时间和精力去思考收取多少租金才算“合理”。
I tried to consider all the variables, including the relative incomes of my tenants, my own income and cash-flow needs, which expenses were for upkeep and which were capital expenses, the equity versus the interest portion of the mortgage payments, how much my labor on the house was worth, etc.
我试图考虑所有变量，包括我的租户的相对收入、我自己的收入和现金流需求、哪些支出是维护费用，哪些是资本支出、抵押贷款支付中的权益部分与利息部分、我在房子上的劳动价值是多少等等。
I got absolutely nowhere. Finally I went to someone who specializes in giving money advice. She said: “You’re acting as though there is a fine line at which the rent is fair, and at any point above that point the tenant is being screwed and at any point below that you are being screwed. In fact, there is a large gray area in which both you and the tenant are getting a good, or at least a fair, deal. Stop worrying and get on with your life.” 4
我完全没有进展。最后，我去找了一位专门提供理财建议的人。她说：“你好像觉得租金有个很微妙的界限，高于这个界限租客就亏大了，低于这个界限租客就亏大了。实际上，存在一个很大的灰色地带，在这个地带你和租客都能得到不错的，或者至少是公平的交易。别再担心了，继续过你的生活吧。”

11. Buffers—The sizes of stabilizing stocks relative to their flows

11. 缓冲——稳定库存相对于其流量的大小

Consider a huge bathtub with slow in- and outflows. Now think about a small one with very fast flows. That’s the difference between a lake and a river. You hear about catastrophic river floods much more often than catastrophic lake floods, because stocks that are big, relative to their flows, are more stable than small ones. In chemistry and other fields, a big, stabilizing stock is known as a buffer.

想象一下一个巨大的浴缸，进出水流缓慢。现在再想象一下一个小浴缸，水流却非常急。这就是湖泊和河流的区别。你听到的灾难性河流洪水比灾难性湖泊洪水要多得多，因为相对于流量而言，水量大的水域比水量小的水域更稳定。在化学和其他领域，这种具有稳定作用的大量水体被称为缓冲带。

The stabilizing power of buffers is why you keep money in the bank rather than living from the flow of change through your pocket. It’s why stores hold inventory instead of calling for new stock just as customers carry the old stock out the door. It’s why we need to maintain more than the minimum breeding population of an endangered species. Soils in the eastern United States are more sensitive to acid rain than soils in the west, because they haven’t got big buffers of calcium to neutralize acid.

缓冲机制的稳定作用正是人们选择将钱存入银行而不是随身携带零钱的原因。这也是为什么商店会储备库存，而不是在顾客刚把旧货搬出店门时就要求补货的原因。同样，这也是为什么我们需要维持濒危物种的种群数量，使其超过最低繁殖数量的原因。美国东部的土壤比西部的土壤更容易受到酸雨的影响，因为它们缺乏大量的钙质缓冲来中和酸性物质。

You can often stabilize a system by increasing the capacity of a buffer. 5 But if a buffer is too big, the system gets inflexible. It reacts too slowly. And big buffers of some sorts, such as water reservoirs or inventories, cost a lot to build or maintain. Businesses invented just-in-time inventories, because occasional vulnerability to fluctuations or screw-ups is cheaper (for them, anyway) than certain, constant inventory costs—and because small-to vanishing inventories allow more flexible response to shifting demand.

通常可以通过增加缓冲区容量来稳定系统。但如果缓冲区过大，系统就会变得僵化，反应迟缓。而且，某些类型的大型缓冲区，例如水库或库存，建设或维护成本很高。企业发明了即时库存管理，因为偶尔应对波动或失误的风险（至少对企业而言）比固定的库存成本更低——而且，少量甚至零库存能够更灵活地应对不断变化的需求。

There’s leverage, sometimes magical, in changing the size of buffers. But buffers are usually physical entities, not easy to change. The acid absorption capacity of eastern soils is not a leverage point for alleviating acid rain damage. The storage capacity of a dam is literally cast in concrete. So I haven’t put buffers very high on the list of leverage points.

改变缓冲带的大小有时确实能起到作用，甚至可以说是神奇。但缓冲带通常是物理实体，不易改变。东部土壤的酸吸收能力并非缓解酸雨损害的有效杠杆点。水坝的蓄水能力是实实在在用混凝土浇筑的。因此，我并没有把缓冲带列为最重要的杠杆点之一。

10. Stock-and-Flow Structures—Physical systems and their nodes of intersection

10. 存量与流量结构——物理系统及其交汇节点

The plumbing structure, the stocks and flows and their physical arrangement, can have an enormous effect on how the system operates. When the Hungarian road system was laid out so all traffic from one side of the nation to the other had to pass through central Budapest, that determined a lot about air pollution and commuting delays that are not easily fixed by pollution control devices, traffic lights, or speed limits.

管道结构、存量和流量及其物理布局会对系统的运行方式产生巨大影响。匈牙利的道路系统规划使得所有从国家一端到另一端的交通都必须经过布达佩斯市中心，这在很大程度上决定了空气污染和通勤延误问题，而这些问题并非污染控制装置、交通信号灯或限速就能轻易解决的。

The only way to fix a system that is laid out poorly is to rebuild it, if you can. Amory Lovins and his team at Rocky Mountain Institute have done wonders on energy conservation by simply straightening out bent pipes and enlarging ones that are too small. If we did similar energy retrofits on all the buildings in the United States, we could shut down many of our electric power plants.

如果系统布局不合理，唯一的解决办法就是重建（如果条件允许的话）。落基山研究所的阿莫里·洛文斯和他的团队通过简单地矫正弯曲的管道和扩大过小的管道，在节能方面取得了显著成效。如果我们对美国所有建筑都进行类似的节能改造，就可以关闭许多发电厂。

But often physical rebuilding is the slowest and most expensive kind of change to make in a system. Some stock-and-flow structures are just plain unchangeable. The baby-boom swell in the U.S. population first caused pressure on the elementary school system, then high schools, then colleges, then jobs and housing, and now we’re supporting its retirement. There’s not much we can do about it, because five-year-olds become six-year-olds, and sixty-four-year-olds become sixty-five-year-olds predictably and unstoppably. The same can be said for the lifetime of destructive CFC molecules in the ozone layer, for the rate at which contaminants get washed out of aquifers, for the fact that an inefficient car fleet takes ten to twenty years to turn over.

但通常来说，对系统进行物理重建是最缓慢、成本最高的变革。有些存量和流量结构根本无法改变。美国人口婴儿潮首先给小学系统带来压力，然后是中学、大学、就业和住房，现在我们正在支持其退休。我们对此无能为力，因为五岁的孩子会变成六岁的孩子，六十四岁的人会变成六十五岁的人，这是可以预见且无法阻止的。臭氧层中破坏性氟氯烃分子的寿命、污染物从含水层中被冲刷出来的速度、低效汽车车队需要十年到二十年才能更新换代，这些情况也同样如此。

Physical structure is crucial in a system, but is rarely a leverage point, because changing it is rarely quick or simple. The leverage point is in proper design in the first place. After the structure is built, the leverage is in understanding its limitations and bottlenecks, using it with maximum efficiency, and refraining from fluctuations or expansions that strain its capacity.

物理结构在系统中至关重要，但很少成为杠杆点，因为改变它往往既不快捷也不简单。真正的杠杆点在于最初的合理设计。结构建成后，杠杆作用体现在理解其局限性和瓶颈，最大限度地提高其效率，并避免任何会超出其承载能力的波动或扩张。

9. Delays—The lengths of time relative to the rates of system changes

9. 延迟——相对于系统变化速率的时间长度

Delays in feedback loops are critical determinants of system behavior. They are common causes of oscillations. If you’re trying to adjust a stock (your store inventory) to meet your goal, but you receive only delayed information about what the state of the stock is, you will overshoot and undershoot your goal. The same is true if your information is timely, but your response isn’t. For example, it takes several years to build an electric power plant that will likely last thirty years. Those delays make it impossible to build exactly the right number of power plants to supply rapidly changing demand for electricity. Even with immense effort at forecasting, almost every electricity industry in the world experiences long oscillations between overcapacity and undercapacity. A system just can’t respond to short-term changes when it has long term delays. That’s why a massive central-planning system, such as the Soviet Union or General Motors, necessarily functions poorly.

反馈回路中的延迟是系统行为的关键决定因素，也是系统振荡的常见原因。如果您试图调整库存（例如商店库存）以达到目标，但您只能获得关于库存状态的延迟信息，那么您就会出现库存过量或不足的情况。如果您的信息及时，但您的响应却不及时，也会出现同样的问题。例如，建造一座可能运行三十年的发电厂需要数年时间。这些延迟使得建造数量恰好满足快速变化的电力需求的发电厂变得不可能。即使投入大量精力进行预测，世界上几乎所有电力行业都会经历产能过剩和产能不足之间的长期波动。当系统存在长期延迟时，它就无法对短期变化做出响应。这就是为什么像苏联或通用汽车这样的大型中央计划系统必然运行不佳的原因。

Because we know they’re important, we see delays wherever we look. For example, the delay between the time when a pollutant is dumped on the land and when it trickles down to the groundwater; or the delay between the birth of a child and the time when that child is ready to have a child; or the delay between the first successful test of a new technology and the time when that technology is installed throughout the economy; or the time it takes for a price to adjust to a supply-demand imbalance.

因为我们知道这些延迟至关重要，所以我们无论走到哪里都能看到它们。例如，污染物倾倒在土地上到渗入地下水之间的延迟；孩子出生到具备生育能力之间的延迟；一项新技术首次成功测试到该技术在整个经济体系中得到应用之间的延迟；以及价格调整以适应供需失衡所需的时间。

A delay in a feedback process is critical relative to rates of change in the stocks that the feedback loop is trying to control . Delays that are too short cause overreaction, “chasing your tail,” oscillations amplified by the jumpiness of the response. Delays that are too long cause damped, sustained, or exploding oscillations, depending on how much too long. Overlong delays in a system with a threshold, a danger point, a range past which irreversible damage can occur, cause overshoot and collapse.

反馈过程中的延迟对于反馈回路试图控制的股票价格变化率至关重要。延迟过短会导致过度反应，即“追逐尾巴”，这种反应的跳跃性会放大波动。延迟过长则会导致衰减性、持续性或爆发性波动，具体取决于延迟过长的程度。在一个存在阈值、危险点（即超过该阈值就会造成不可逆转损害的范围）的系统中，过长的延迟会导致过度反应和崩溃。

I would list delay length as a high leverage point, except for the fact that delays are not often easily changeable. Things take as long as they take. You can’t do a lot about the construction time of a major piece of capital, or the maturation time of a child, or the growth rate of a forest. It’s usually easier to slow down the change rate , so that inevitable feedback delays won’t cause so much trouble. That’s why growth rates are higher up on the leverage point list than delay times.

我本想把延迟时间列为重要的杠杆点，但问题在于延迟时间往往难以改变。事情发生的时间就是如此。你无法左右大型项目的建设时间、孩子的成长周期或森林的生长速度。通常，减缓变化的速度更容易，这样不可避免的反馈延迟就不会造成太大的麻烦。这就是为什么增长率在杠杆点列表中比延迟时间更重要的原因。

And that’s why slowing economic growth is a greater leverage point in Forrester’s World model than faster technological development or freer market prices. Those are attempts to speed up the rate of adjustment. But the world’s physical capital stock, its factories and boilers, the concrete manifestations of its working technologies, can change only so fast, even in the face of new prices or new ideas—and prices and ideas don’t change instantly either, not through a whole global culture. There’s more leverage in slowing the system down so technologies and prices can keep up with it, than there is in wishing the delays would go away.

因此，在福雷斯特的世界模型中，放缓经济增长比加快技术发展或实行更自由的市场价格更能起到作用。后者旨在加快调整速度，但世界的物质资本存量——工厂和锅炉，以及其运行技术的具体体现——即使面对新的价格或新的理念，其变化速度也终究有限。而价格和理念的改变也并非一蹴而就，更何况是整个全球文化。与其寄希望于延迟消失，不如放慢系统运行速度，让技术和价格跟上步伐，这样才能发挥更大的作用。

But if there is a delay in your system that can be changed, changing it can have big effects. Watch out! Be sure you change it in the right direction! (For example, the great push to reduce information and money-transfer delays in financial markets is just asking for wild gyrations.)

但如果系统中存在可以改变的延迟，那么改变它可能会产生巨大的影响。务必小心！确保朝着正确的方向改变！（例如，大力推动减少金融市场的信息和资金转移延迟，只会引发剧烈的市场波动。）

8. Balancing Feedback Loops—The strength of the feedbacks relative to the impacts they are trying to correct

8. 平衡反馈回路——反馈的强度相对于它们试图纠正的影响而言是否合适

Now we’re beginning to move from the physical part of the system to the information and control parts, where more leverage can be found.

现在我们开始从系统的物理部分转向信息和控制部分，在这些部分可以找到更大的作用。

Balancing feedback loops are ubiquitous in systems. Nature evolves them and humans invent them as controls to keep important stocks within safe bounds. A thermostat loop is the classic example. Its purpose is to keep the system stock called “temperature of the room” fairly constant near a desired level. Any balancing feedback loop needs a goal (the thermostat setting), a monitoring and signaling device to detect deviation from the goal (the thermostat), and a response mechanism (the furnace and/or air conditioner, fans, pumps, pipes, fuel, etc.).

平衡反馈回路在各种系统中普遍存在。自然界进化出了它们，人类也发明了它们，作为控制手段，将重要的资源维持在安全范围内。恒温器回路就是一个经典的例子。它的目的是使被称为“房间温度”的系统资源保持在接近目标值的稳定状态。任何平衡反馈回路都需要一个目标（恒温器设定值）、一个用于检测与目标值偏差的监控和信号装置（恒温器本身）以及一个响应机制（例如炉子和/或空调、风扇、水泵、管道、燃料等）。

A complex system usually has numerous balancing feedback loops it can bring into play, so it can self-correct under different conditions and impacts. Some of those loops may be inactive much of the time—like the emergency cooling system in a nuclear power plant, or your ability to sweat or shiver to maintain your body temperature—but their presence is critical to the long term welfare of the system.

一个复杂的系统通常拥有众多平衡反馈回路，可以在不同的条件和影响下进行自我调节。其中一些回路可能大部分时间都处于非激活状态——例如核电站的应急冷却系统，或者人体通过出汗或颤抖来维持体温的能力——但它们的存在对于系统的长期健康至关重要。

One of the big mistakes we make is to strip away these “emergency” response mechanisms because they aren’t often used and they appear to be costly. In the short term, we see no effect from doing this. In the long term, we drastically narrow the range of conditions over which the system can survive. One of the most heartbreaking ways we do this is in encroaching on the habitats of endangered species. Another is in encroaching on our own time for personal rest, recreation, socialization, and meditation.

我们犯的一个重大错误是，因为这些“紧急”响应机制不常用且看起来成本高昂，就将其取消。短期来看，这样做似乎没有效果。但从长远来看，我们会大幅缩小系统能够生存的条件范围。我们造成这种局面的最令人痛心的方式之一，就是侵占濒危物种的栖息地。另一个方式是侵占我们个人休息、娱乐、社交和冥想的时间。

The strength of a balancing loop—its ability to keep its appointed stock at or near its goal—depends on the combination of all its parameters and links—the accuracy and rapidity of monitoring, the quickness and power of response, the directness and size of corrective flows. Sometimes there are leverage points here.

平衡回路的强度——即其维持目标库存水平在目标值或接近目标值的能力——取决于所有参数和环节的组合：监测的准确性和速度、响应的迅速性和力度、以及纠正措施的直接性和规模。有时，这里存在着一些关键的杠杆点。

Take markets, for example, the balancing feedback systems that are all but worshipped by many economists. They can indeed be marvels of self correction, as prices vary to moderate supply and demand and keep them in balance. Price is the central piece of information signaling both producers and consumers. The more the price is kept clear, unambiguous, timely, and truthful, the more smoothly markets will operate. Prices that reflect full costs will tell consumers how much they can actually afford and will reward efficient producers. Companies and governments are fatally attracted to the price leverage point, but too often determinedly push it in the wrong direction with subsidies, taxes, and other forms of confusion.

以市场为例，这种平衡反馈系统几乎被许多经济学家奉为圭臬。市场的确是自我调节的奇迹，价格波动能够调节供求关系，使其保持平衡。价格是向生产者和消费者传递信息的核心要素。价格越清晰、明确、及时、真实，市场运行就越顺畅。反映全部成本的价格能够让消费者了解他们实际的购买力，并奖励高效的生产者。企业和政府都对价格杠杆点有着致命的吸引力，但他们却常常通过补贴、税收和其他形式的混乱手段，执意将价格推向错误的方向。

These modifications weaken the feedback power of market signals by twisting information in their favor. The real leverage here is to keep them from doing it. Hence, the necessity of antitrust laws, truth-in-advertising laws, attempts to internalize costs (such as pollution fees), the removal of perverse subsidies, and other ways of leveling market playing fields.

这些修改通过扭曲信息使其有利于自身，从而削弱了市场信号的反馈效力。真正的关键在于阻止他们这样做。因此，反垄断法、广告真实性法、成本内部化措施（例如污染费）、取消不正当补贴以及其他旨在创造公平市场竞争环境的措施都必不可少。

Strengthening and clarifying market signals, such as full-cost accounting, don’t get far these days, because of the weakening of another set of balancing feedback loops—those of democracy. This great system was invented to put self-correcting feedback between the people and their government. The people, informed about what their elected representatives do, respond by voting those representatives in or out of office. The process depends on the free, full, unbiased flow of information back and forth between electorate and leaders. Billions of dollars are spent to limit and bias and dominate that flow of clear information. Give the people who want to distort market-price signals the power to influence government leaders, allow the distributors of information to be self-interested partners, and none of the necessary balancing feedbacks work well. Both market and democracy erode.

如今，加强和澄清市场信号（例如全面成本核算）收效甚微，原因在于另一套平衡反馈机制——民主机制——的削弱。这套伟大的制度旨在建立人民与政府之间的自我纠正反馈机制。人民了解其民选代表的所作所为，并通过投票来决定这些代表的去留。这一过程依赖于选民与领导人之间自由、充分、公正的信息交流。然而，数十亿美元却被用来限制、偏袒和控制这种清晰的信息流动。如果赋予那些意图扭曲市场价格信号的人影响政府领导人的权力，允许信息传播者成为自私自利的伙伴，那么所有必要的平衡反馈机制都将失效。市场和民主都将受到侵蚀。

The strength of a balancing feedback loop is important relative to the impact it is designed to correct . If the impact increases in strength, the feedbacks have to be strengthened too. A thermostat system may work fine on a cold winter day—but open all the windows and its corrective power is no match for the temperature change imposed on the system. Democracy works better without the brainwashing power of centralized mass communications. Traditional controls on fishing were sufficient until sonar spotting and drift nets and other technologies made it possible for a few actors to catch the last fish. The power of big industry calls for the power of big government to hold it in check; a global economy makes global regulations necessary.

平衡反馈回路的强度与其旨在纠正的影响密切相关。如果影响增强，反馈也必须相应加强。恒温器系统在寒冷的冬日可能运行良好，但如果打开所有窗户，其调节能力就无法应对系统所承受的温度变化。民主制度若缺乏集中式大众传播的洗脑力量，则运作得更好。传统的捕鱼管制措施原本足够有效，直到声呐探测、流网和其他技术的出现，使得少数人能够捕捞到最后一批鱼。大型企业的强大力量需要强大的政府力量来制约；全球经济使得全球监管成为必要。

Examples of strengthening balancing feedback controls to improve a system’s self-correcting abilities include:

加强平衡反馈控制以提高系统自纠正能力的例子包括：

• preventive medicine, exercise, and good nutrition to bolster the body’s ability to fight disease,
• 预防医学、运动和良好的营养，以增强身体抵抗疾病的能力，
• integrated pest management to encourage natural predators of crop pests,
• 综合虫害管理，以鼓励作物害虫的天敌繁殖，
• the Freedom of Information Act to reduce government secrecy,
• 《信息自由法》旨在减少政府保密行为，
• monitoring systems to report on environmental damage,
• 用于报告环境损害的监测系统，
• protection for whistleblowers, and
• 对举报人的保护，以及
• impact fees, pollution taxes, and performance bonds to recapture the externalized public costs of private benefits.
• 征收影响费、污染税和履约保证金，以收回私人收益的外部化公共成本。

7. Reinforcing Feedback Loops—The strength of the gain of driving loops

7. 增强反馈回路——驱动回路增益的强度

A balancing feedback loop is self-correcting; a reinforcing feedback loop is self-reinforcing. The more it works, the more it gains power to work some more, driving system behavior in one direction. The more people catch the flu, the more they infect other people. The more babies are born, the more people grow up to have babies. The more money you have in the bank, the more interest you earn, the more money you have in the bank. The more the soil erodes, the less vegetation it can support, the fewer roots and leaves to soften rain and runoff, the more soil erodes. The more high-energy neutrons in the critical mass, the more they knock into nuclei and generate more high-energy neutrons, leading to a nuclear explosion or meltdown.

平衡反馈回路具有自我纠正功能；增强反馈回路则具有自我增强功能。它运作得越多，就越能增强自身运作能力，从而驱动系统朝着一个方向发展。例如，感染流感的人越多，传染给其他人的也就越多。婴儿出生得越多，长大后生育的人也就越多。银行存款越多，获得的利息就越多，存款也就越多。土壤侵蚀越严重，能够支撑的植被就越少，根系和树叶就越少，从而无法更好地缓冲雨水和径流，土壤侵蚀也就越严重。临界质量中高能中子越多，它们撞击原子核并产生更多高能中子的次数就越多，最终导致核爆炸或堆芯熔毁。

Reinforcing feedback loops are sources of growth, explosion, erosion, and collapse in systems. A system with an unchecked reinforcing loop ultimately will destroy itself. That’s why there are so few of them. Usually a balancing loop will kick in sooner or later. The epidemic will run out of infectible people—or people will take increasingly stronger steps to avoid being infected. The death rate will rise to equal the birth rate—or people will see the consequences of unchecked population growth and have fewer babies. The soil will erode away to bedrock, and after a million years the bedrock will crumble into new soil—or people will stop overgrazing, put up check dams, plant trees, and stop the erosion.

正反馈回路是系统中增长、爆发、侵蚀和崩溃的根源。一个拥有不受控制的正反馈回路的系统最终会自我毁灭。这就是为什么这类系统如此罕见的原因。通常，平衡回路迟早会启动。疫情会随着感染人数的减少而结束——或者人们会采取越来越强有力的措施来避免感染。死亡率会上升到与出生率相等——或者人们会意识到人口无节制增长的后果，从而减少生育。土壤会被侵蚀到基岩，经过百万年的时间，基岩会崩塌形成新的土壤——或者人们会停止过度放牧，修建拦水坝，植树造林，从而阻止侵蚀。

In all those examples, the first outcome is what will happen if the reinforcing loop runs its course, the second is what will happen if there’s an intervention to reduce its self-multiplying power. Reducing the gain around a reinforcing loop—slowing the growth—is usually a more powerful leverage point in systems than strengthening balancing loops, and far more preferable than letting the reinforcing loop run.

在所有这些例子中，第一个结果是如果强化回路继续运行下去会发生什么，第二个结果是如果采取干预措施降低其自我放大能力会发生什么。降低强化回路的增益——减缓其增长速度——通常比加强平衡回路更能有效地影响系统，也远比放任强化回路运行要好得多。

Population and economic growth rates in the World model are leverage points, because slowing them gives the many balancing loops, through technology and markets and other forms of adaptation (all of which have limits and delays), time to function. It’s the same as slowing the car when you’re driving too fast, rather than calling for more responsive brakes or technical advances in steering.

世界模型中的人口和经济增长率是关键的杠杆点，因为减缓这些增长速度能让众多平衡机制——通过技术、市场和其他适应方式（所有这些都存在局限性和延迟）——有时间发挥作用。这就像开车速度过快时减速，而不是要求提高刹车灵敏度或改进转向系统技术一样。

There are many reinforcing feedback loops in society that reward the winners of a competition with the resources to win even bigger next time—the “success to the successful” trap. Rich people collect interest; poor people pay it. Rich people pay accountants and lean on politicians to reduce their taxes; poor people can’t. Rich people give their kids inheritances and good educations. Antipoverty programs are weak balancing loops that try to counter these strong reinforcing ones. It would be much more effective to weaken the reinforcing loops. That’s what progressive income tax, inheritance tax, and universal high-quality public education programs are meant to do. If the wealthy can influence government to weaken, rather than strengthen, those measures, then the government itself shifts from a balancing structure to one that reinforces success to the successful!

社会中存在许多相互强化的反馈回路，它们奖励竞争中的赢家，让他们拥有更多资源在下次竞争中取得更大的胜利——这就是所谓的“成功者胜”陷阱。富人赚取利息，穷人支付利息。富人聘请会计师，游说政客减税，穷人却无能为力。富人给子女留下遗产和良好的教育。反贫困项目就像是脆弱的平衡回路，试图抵消这些强大的强化回路。更有效的做法是削弱这些强化回路。累进所得税、遗产税和普及优质公共教育项目正是旨在实现这一目标。如果富人能够影响政府，使其削弱而非加强这些措施，那么政府本身就会从平衡结构转变为强化成功者胜的机制！

Look for leverage points around birth rates, interest rates, erosion rates, “success to the successful” loops, any place where the more you have of something, the more you have the possibility of having more.

寻找与出生率、利率、侵蚀率、“成功者互惠”循环相关的杠杆点，任何你拥有的某样东西越多，你拥有更多的可能性就越大的地方。

6. Information Flows—The structure of who does and does not have access to information

6. 信息流——信息获取渠道的结构

In Chapter Four, we examined the story of the electric meter in a Dutch housing development—in some of the houses the meter was installed in the basement; in others it was installed in the front hall. With no other differences in the houses, electricity consumption was 30 percent lower in the houses where the meter was in the highly visible location in the front hall.

在第四章中，我们探讨了荷兰某住宅区电表的安装情况——有些房屋的电表安装在地下室，有些则安装在前厅。在其他条件相同的情况下，电表安装在前厅显眼位置的房屋，用电量却降低了30%。

I love that story because it’s an example of a high leverage point in the information structure of the system. It’s not a parameter adjustment, not a strengthening or weakening of an existing feedback loop. It’s a new loop, delivering feedback to a place where it wasn’t going before.

我喜欢这个故事，因为它展现了系统信息结构中的一个高杠杆点。这并非参数调整，也不是对现有反馈回路的加强或削弱，而是一个全新的回路，将反馈传递到之前从未到达过的地方。

Missing information flows is one of the most common causes of system malfunction. Adding or restoring information can be a powerful intervention, usually much easier and cheaper than rebuilding physical infrastructure. The tragedy of the commons that is crashing the world’s commercial fisheries occurs because there is little feedback from the state of the fish population to the decision to invest in fishing vessels. Contrary to economic opinion, the price of fish doesn’t provide that feedback. As the fish get more scarce they become more expensive, and it becomes all the more profitable to go out and catch the last few. That’s a perverse feedback, a reinforcing loop that leads to collapse. It is not price information but population information that is needed.

信息流缺失是系统故障最常见的原因之一。补充或恢复信息是一种强有力的干预措施，通常比重建实体基础设施更容易、更经济。导致全球商业渔业崩溃的“公地悲剧”源于鱼类种群状况与渔船投资决策之间缺乏有效的反馈机制。与经济学观点相反，鱼价并不能提供这种反馈。随着鱼类资源日益稀缺，价格也随之上涨，因此出海捕捞最后几条鱼的利润也随之增加。这是一种恶性循环，一个导致崩溃的正向反馈机制。我们需要的不是价格信息，而是种群信息。

It’s important that the missing feedback be restored to the right place and in compelling form. To take another tragedy of the commons example, it’s not enough to inform all the users of an aquifer that the groundwater level is dropping. That could initiate a race to the bottom. It would be more effective to set the cost of water to rise steeply as the pumping rate begins to exceed the recharge rate.

重要的是，要将缺失的反馈机制以有效且令人信服的方式恢复到正确的位置。再举一个公地悲剧的例子，仅仅告知所有含水层用户地下水位正在下降是不够的，这可能会引发竞相压价的恶性竞争。更有效的做法是，当抽水速率超过补给速率时，大幅提高水价。

Other examples of compelling feedback are not hard to find. Suppose taxpayers got to specify on their return forms what government services their tax payments must be spent on. (Radical democracy!) Suppose any town or company that puts a water intake pipe in a river had to put it immediately downstream from its own wastewater outflow pipe. Suppose any public or private official who made the decision to invest in a nuclear power plant got the waste from that facility stored on his or her lawn. Suppose (this is an old one) the politicians who declare war were required to spend that war in the front lines.

其他令人信服的反馈例子不难找到。假设纳税人可以在纳税申报表上指定他们的税款必须用于哪些政府服务。（激进民主！）假设任何城镇或公司在河中安装取水管道时，都必须将其安装在自身废水排放管道的下游。假设任何决定投资核电站的公职人员或私人官员，都必须将该电站产生的核废料储存在自家草坪上。假设（这是一个老生常谈的例子）宣战的政治家必须亲自上前线作战。

There is a systematic tendency on the part of human beings to avoid accountability for their own decisions. That’s why there are so many missing feedback loops—and why this kind of leverage point is so often popular with the masses, unpopular with the powers that be, and effective, if you can get the powers that be to permit it to happen (or go around them and make it happen anyway).

人类有一种系统性的倾向，那就是逃避为自己的决定承担责任。这就是为什么会有这么多反馈机制缺失——以及为什么这种杠杆点往往受到大众欢迎，却不受当权者欢迎，而且如果你能让当权者允许它发生（或者绕过他们强行让它发生），它就会有效。

5. Rules—Incentives, punishments, constraints

5. 规则——激励、惩罚、限制

The rules of the system define its scope, its boundaries, its degrees of freedom. Thou shalt not kill. Everyone has the right of free speech. Contracts are to be honored. The president serves four-year terms and cannot serve more than two of them. Nine people on a team, you have to touch every base, three strikes and you’re out. If you get caught robbing a bank, you go to jail.

制度的规则界定了它的范围、边界和自由程度。不可杀人。人人享有言论自由。合同必须履行。总统任期四年，不得连任超过两届。九人一组，必须击中每个垒位，三次出局即出局。抢银行被抓，必入狱。

Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in the Soviet Union and opened information flows (glasnost) and changed the economic rules (perestroika), and the Soviet Union saw tremendous change.

米哈伊尔·戈尔巴乔夫在苏联掌权，开放了信息流通（公开性），改变了经济规则（改革），苏联发生了巨大的变化。

Constitutions are the strongest examples of social rules. Physical laws such as the second law of thermodynamics are absolute rules, whether we understand them or not or like them or not. Laws, punishments, incentives, and informal social agreements are progressively weaker rules.

宪法是社会规则最强有力的例证。物理定律，例如热力学第二定律，是绝对规则，无论我们是否理解或喜欢它们。法律、惩罚、激励措施和非正式的社会约定，其规则效力则依次递减。

To demonstrate the power of rules, I like to ask my students to imagine different ones for a college. Suppose the students graded the teachers, or each other. Suppose there were no degrees: You come to college when you want to learn something, and you leave when you’ve learned it. Suppose tenure were awarded to professors according to their ability to solve real world problems, rather than to publish academic papers. Suppose a class got graded as a group, instead of as individuals.

为了展示规则的力量，我喜欢让学生们设想一下大学里不同的规则。假设学生给老师打分，或者互相打分。假设没有学位：你来大学是为了学习知识，学完知识就离开。假设教授的终身教职是根据他们解决实际问题的能力而不是发表学术论文的数量来授予的。假设班级成绩是作为一个整体而不是以个人为单位来评定的。

As we try to imagine restructured rules and what our behavior would be under them, we come to understand the power of rules. They are high leverage points. Power over the rules is real power. That’s why lobbyists congregate when Congress writes laws, and why the Supreme Court, which interprets and delineates the Constitution—the rules for writing the rules—has even more power than Congress. If you want to understand the deepest malfunctions of systems, pay attention to the rules and to who has power over them.

当我们试图设想重组后的规则以及在这些规则下我们的行为会如何时，我们便会理解规则的力量。它们是极具影响力的杠杆点。掌控规则的力量才是真正的权力。这就是为什么游说集团会在国会制定法律时聚集在一起，以及为什么最高法院——负责解释和阐明宪法（即制定规则的规则）——拥有比国会更大的权力。如果你想了解系统最深层的故障所在，那就关注规则以及谁掌握着规则的权力。

That’s why my systems intuition was sending off alarm bells as the new world trade system was explained to me. It is a system with rules designed by corporations, run by corporations, for the benefit of corporations. Its rules exclude almost any feedback from any other sector of society. Most of its meetings are closed even to the press (no information flow, no feedback). It forces nations into reinforcing loops “racing to the bottom,” competing with each other to weaken environmental and social safeguards in order to attract corporate investment. It’s a recipe for unleashing “success to the successful” loops, until they generate enormous accumulations of power and huge centralized planning systems that will destroy themselves.

这就是为什么当有人向我解释新的世界贸易体系时，我的系统直觉会发出警报。这是一个由企业制定规则、由企业运营、最终服务于企业利益的体系。它的规则几乎排除了来自社会其他任何部门的反馈。它的大部分会议甚至对媒体都是封闭的（没有信息流通，没有反馈）。它迫使各国陷入“竞相降低标准”的恶性循环，彼此竞争削弱环境和社会保障，以吸引企业投资。这注定会释放出“成功者胜者为王”的恶性循环，直到权力高度集中，形成庞大的中央计划体系，最终走向自我毁灭。

4. Self-Organization—The power to add, change, or evolve system structure

4. 自组织——增加、改变或演化系统结构的能力

The most stunning thing living systems and some social systems can do is to change themselves utterly by creating whole new structures and behaviors. In biological systems that power is called evolution. In human economies it’s called technical advance or social revolution. In systems lingo it’s called self-organization.

生命系统和某些社会系统最令人惊叹的能力莫过于通过创造全新的结构和行为来彻底改变自身。在生物系统中，这种力量被称为进化；在人类经济中，它被称为技术进步或社会革命；而在系统学中，它被称为自组织。

Self-organization means changing any aspect of a system lower on this list—adding completely new physical structures, such as brains or wings or computers—adding new balancing or reinforcing loops, or new rules. The ability to self-organize is the strongest form of system resilience. A system that can evolve can survive almost any change, by changing itself. The human immune system has the power to develop new responses to some kinds of insults it has never before encountered. The human brain can take in new information and pop out completely new thoughts.

自组织是指改变系统中任何低于此列表的方面——例如添加全新的物理结构，如大脑、翅膀或计算机；添加新的平衡或增强回路；或制定新的规则。自组织能力是系统韧性的最强形式。能够进化的系统几乎可以通过自我改变来适应任何变化。人类免疫系统有能力对从未遇到过的某些损伤产生新的反应。人脑可以接收新信息并产生全新的思维。

The power of self-organization seems so wondrous that we tend to regard it as mysterious, miraculous, heaven sent. Economists often model technology as magic—coming from nowhere, costing nothing, increasing the productivity of an economy by some steady percent each year. For centuries people have regarded the spectacular variety of nature with the same awe. Only a divine creator could bring forth such a creation.

自组织的力量如此奇妙，以至于我们往往将其视为神秘莫测、奇迹般的存在，甚至是上天的恩赐。经济学家常常将技术比作魔法——凭空出现，无需任何成本，每年都能使经济生产力稳定增长一定百分比。几个世纪以来，人们也以同样的敬畏之心看待大自然的壮丽多样性。只有神圣的造物主才能创造出如此奇妙的景象。

Further investigation of self-organizing systems reveals that the divine creator, if there is one, does not have to produce evolutionary miracles. He, she, or it just has to write marvelously clever rules for self-organization . These rules basically govern how, where, and what the system can add onto or subtract from itself under what conditions. As hundreds of self-organizing computer models have demonstrated, complex and delightful patterns can evolve from quite simple sets of rules. The genetic code within the DNA that is the basis of all biological evolution contains just four different letters, combined into words of three letters each. That pattern, and the rules for replicating and rearranging it, has been constant for something like three billion years, during which it has spewed out an unimaginable variety of failed and successful self-evolved creatures.

对自组织系统的进一步研究表明，如果真有造物主存在，祂无需创造进化奇迹。祂只需编写精妙绝伦的自组织规则即可。这些规则基本上决定了系统在何种条件下、何地、如何进行自我增减。正如数百个自组织计算机模型所展示的那样，复杂而奇妙的模式可以从相当简单的规则集中演化而来。构成所有生物进化基础的DNA遗传密码仅包含四种不同的字母，它们组合成由三个字母组成的单词。这种模式及其复制和重组规则在大约30亿年的时间里保持不变，在此期间，它孕育了无数种自我进化失败和成功的生物。

Self-organization is basically a matter of an evolutionary raw material—a highly variable stock of information from which to select possible patterns—and a means for experimentation, for selecting and testing new patterns. For biological evolution, the raw material is DNA, one source of variety is spontaneous mutation, and the testing mechanism is a changing environment in which some individuals do not survive to reproduce. For technology, the raw material is the body of understanding science has accumulated and stored in libraries and in the brains of its practitioners. The source of variety is human creativity (whatever that is) and the selection mechanism can be whatever the market will reward, or whatever governments and foundations will fund, or whatever meets human needs.

自组织本质上取决于进化的原材料——一个高度可变的信息库，从中选择可能的模式——以及一种实验手段，即选择和测试新模式的手段。对于生物进化而言，原材料是DNA，多样性的来源之一是自发突变，而测试机制则是不断变化的环境，在这种环境中，一些个体无法生存繁衍。对于技术而言，原材料是科学积累并储存在图书馆和从业者大脑中的理解体系。多样性的来源是人类的创造力（无论其具体形式如何），而选择机制可以是市场奖励的、政府和基金会资助的，或者任何能够满足人类需求的。

When you understand the power of system self-organization, you begin to understand why biologists worship biodiversity even more than economists worship technology. The wildly varied stock of DNA, evolved and accumulated over billions of years, is the source of evolutionary potential, just as science libraries and labs and universities where scientists are trained are the source of technological potential. Allowing species to go extinct is a systems crime, just as randomly eliminating all copies of particular science journals or particular kinds of scientists would be.

当你理解了系统自组织的力量，你就会明白为什么生物学家对生物多样性的崇拜甚至超过了经济学家对技术的崇拜。数十亿年来进化和积累的极其丰富的DNA库是进化潜力的源泉，正如科学图书馆、实验室和培养科学家的大学是技术潜力的源泉一样。任由物种灭绝是一种系统犯罪，就像随意销毁所有特定科学期刊或特定类型的科学家一样。

The same could be said of human cultures, of course, which are the store of behavioral repertoires, accumulated over not billions, but hundreds of thousands of years. They are a stock out of which social evolution can arise. Unfortunately, people appreciate the precious evolutionary potential of cultures even less than they understand the preciousness of every genetic variation in the world’s ground squirrels. I guess that’s because one aspect of almost every culture is the belief in the utter superiority of that culture.

当然，人类文化也是如此。它们是行为模式的宝库，这些模式并非历经数十亿年，而是数十万年才积累起来的。它们是社会进化的源泉。可惜的是，人们对文化所蕴含的宝贵进化潜力的认识，甚至不如对世界上每一种地松鼠基因变异的珍贵程度。我想，这大概是因为几乎每一种文化都存在一个共同点：那就是坚信自身文化的绝对优越性。

Insistence on a single culture shuts down learning and cuts back resilience. Any system, biological, economic, or social, that gets so encrusted that it cannot self-evolve, a system that systematically scorns experimentation and wipes out the raw material of innovation, is doomed over the long term on this highly variable planet.

坚持单一文化会扼杀学习，削弱适应力。任何系统，无论是生物的、经济的还是社会的，如果僵化到无法自我进化，如果系统性地蔑视实验，扼杀创新的原材料，那么在这个变化莫测的星球上，从长远来看注定会走向灭亡。

The intervention point here is obvious, but unpopular. Encouraging variability and experimentation and diversity means “losing control.” Let a thousand flowers bloom and anything could happen! Who wants that? Let’s play it safe and push this lever in the wrong direction by wiping out biological, cultural, social, and market diversity!

这里的干预点显而易见，但却不受欢迎。鼓励变异、实验和多样性意味着“失去控制”。任由百花盛开，什么都可能发生！谁想要那样？让我们求稳妥，却把方向推向错误的方向，抹杀生物、文化、社会和市场的多样性！

3. Goals—The purpose or function of the system

3. 目标——系统的目的或功能

Right there, the diversity-destroying consequence of the push for control demonstrates why the goal of a system is a leverage point superior to the self-organizing ability of a system.
